He invites Venerable Ānanda to explain in detail the stages of spiritual practice for a lay trainee.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'mn54', 'root_name': 'Potaliyasutta', 'translated_name': 'With Potaliya the Householder ', 'acronym': 'MN 54', 'blurb': 'When Potaliya got upset at being referred to as “householder”, the Buddha quizzed him as to the true nature of attachment and renunciation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn55', 'root_name': 'Jīvakasutta', 'translated_name': 'With Jīvaka ', 'acronym': 'MN 55', 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s personal doctor, Jīvaka, hears criticisms of the Buddha’s policy regarding eating meat, and asks him about it.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn56', 'root_name': 'Upālisutta', 'translated_name': 'With Upāli ', 'acronym': 'MN 56', 'blurb': 'The Buddha disagrees with a Jain ascetic on the question of whether physical or mental deeds are more important. [{'uid': 'sn46.51', 'root_name': 'Āhārasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.51', 'blurb': 'The Buddha spells out in detail the factors that nourish the hindrances, and those that nourish the awakening factors.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn46.52', 'root_name': 'Pariyāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.52', 'blurb': 'Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains by giving a detailed analytical treatment that he says is beyond the scope of the wanderers.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn46.53', 'root_name': 'Aggisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.53', 'blurb': 'Which awakening factors should be developed when the mind is tired, and which when it is energetic? And what is always useful?', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn46.54', 'root_name': 'Mettāsahagatasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.54', 'blurb': 'Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the four Brahmā meditations, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains the detailed connection between the Brahmā meditations and the awakening factors, which taken together lead to liberation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn46.55', 'root_name': 'Saṅgāravasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.55', 'blurb': 'The brahmin Saṅgārava asks why sometimes verses stay in memory while other times they don’t. The Buddha replies that it is due to the presence of either the hindrances of awakening factors. He gives a set of similes illustrating each of the hindrances with different bowls of water.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn46.56', 'root_name': 'Abhayasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 46.56', 'blurb': 'Prince Abhaya reports Pūraṇa Kassapa’s view that there is no cause for ignorance or knowledge, and asks the Buddha’s opinion. The Buddha replies that the cause of ignorance is the hindrances, and the cause of knowledge is the awakening factors.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The Netti or “Guide” is a systematic treatise intended to provide a guide for reading and interpreting the texts of the nikāyas. It is similar to the Peṭakopadesa, and the exact relationship between these two texts is not clear. The text provides an array of methods for reading texts, illustrating them with quotations, and taking the four noble truths as the overall framework. A colophon in the text attributes it to the Buddha's disciple Kaccāna. It is, however, a late text, lacking counterparts in the northern collections. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral’s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.

[4951 Oh the contented nature of Tathagatas!” When the Master came and on inquiry learned the nature of their discussion he said, “It is no marvel, Brethren, that a Tathagata now has lost all covetousness, seeing that formerly when born in an animal form he forsook covetousness.” And hereupon he told a story of the past. For the hurricane that smites Mount Sineru is not ashamed to carry off a withered leaf. blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Causation” is a major collection containing 93 discourses on the core Buddhist teaching of dependent origination. Dependent origination presents a series of conditional links laying bare how suffering originates and how it ends. As such, it is an extended treatment of the second and third noble truths. It integrates psychological and existential aspects of suffering, showing how when bound by attachment we make choices that bind us to transmigrating into future lives. One of the core purposes is to explain how rebirth takes place without having to invoke metaphysical concepts such as a “soul”. The collection begins by defining each of the terms in the standard 12-linked chain, definitions which are assumed to apply throughout. Remaining discourses iterate on this theme, introducing new perspectives and formulations.

blurb: 29 shorter discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at sūtra numbers 126–151, following the complete Ekottarikāgama collection. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Ekottara, made at various times by various translators.

[{'uid': 'sn24.1', 'root_name': 'Vātasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 24.1', 'blurb': 'The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates. But by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent, such a view is given up and one becomes a stream-enterer.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': children: [{'uid': 'sn48.1', 'root_name': 'Suddhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 48.1', 'blurb': 'The five faculties are faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.', 'Paṭhamasotāpannasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 48.2', 'blurb': 'One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a [{'uid': 'sn35.94', 'root_name': 'Adantaaguttasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.94', 'blurb': 'The six fields of contact lead to suffering if left unguarded, but if guarded lead to happiness. A lengthy set of verses illustrate this.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.95', 'root_name': 'Mālukyaputtasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.95', 'blurb': 'Venerable Māluṅkyaputta asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha wonders how to teach an old monk like him, then questions him on his desire for sense experience that has been or might be, and encourages him to simply let sense experience be. Māluṅkyaputta says he understands, and expands the Buddha’s teaching in a series of verses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.96', 'root_name': 'Parihānadhammasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.96', 'blurb': 'When a mendicant tolerates evil thoughts that arise from the senses, they are liable to decline. If they don’t tolerate them, they’re not liable to decline. When such thoughts not longer arise, they have mastered the senses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.97', 'root_name': 'Pamādavihārīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.97', 'blurb': 'When a mendicant lives without restraint regarding the senses, they are negligent. If they have restraint, they are diligent.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.98', 'root_name': 'Saṁvarasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.98', 'blurb': 'Non-restraint is delighting in the senses, restraint is not delighting in them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.99', 'root_name': 'Samādhisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.99', 'blurb': 'Develop meditative immersion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.100', 'root_name': 'Paṭisallānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.100', 'blurb': 'Develop seclusion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.101', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamanatumhākasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.101', 'blurb': 'Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.102', 'root_name': 'Dutiyanatumhākasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.102', 'blurb': 'Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.103', 'root_name': 'Udakasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.103', 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s former teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta claimed to be a knowledge master, a universal victor, who had excised the tumor. But a true knowledge master understands the senses, a victor is freed from them, and excising the tumor is being free from attachment to the body.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

[{'uid': 'sn35.124', 'root_name': 'Vesālīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.124', 'blurb': 'At the Great Wood, the householder Ugga of Vesālī asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.125', 'root_name': 'Vajjīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.125', 'blurb': 'At Hatthigāma, the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.126', 'root_name': 'Nāḷandasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.126', 'blurb': 'At Nālandā, the householder Upāli asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.127', 'root_name': 'Bhāradvājasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.127', 'blurb': 'King Udena of Kosambi asks Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja how even young monks can maintain the celibate life. Piṇḍola says it’s because they see women as their sisters, mothers, or daughters. If this doesn’t work, they meditate on the ugliness of the body. Finally they exercise sense restraint.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.128', 'root_name': 'Soṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.128', 'blurb': 'At Rājagaha, the householder Soṇa asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.129', 'root_name': 'Ghositasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.129', 'blurb': 'The householder Ghosita asks Ānanda about the diversity of elements, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.130', 'root_name': 'Hāliddikānisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.130', 'blurb': 'The householder Hāliddakāni asks Mahākaccāna about the relation between the diversity of elements and the diversity of contacts, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.131', 'root_name': 'Nakulapitusutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.131', 'blurb': 'At Suṁsumāragira, the householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.132', 'root_name': 'Lohiccasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.132', 'blurb': 'Students of the brahmin Lohicca make a racket while collecting firewood near Mahākaccāna’s hut. Mahākaccāna hushes them and recites a series of verses contrasting the virtuous brahmins of old with those of today. Taking umbrage, they tell Lohicca, who goes to Mahākaccāna to ascertain the truth. But when Lohicca hears what Mahākaccāna teach on the six senses, he is so impressed he goes for refuge.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.133', 'root_name': 'Verahaccānisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.133', 'blurb': 'A student of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan recommends to her the teaching of Venerable Udāyı̄, so she invites him for a meal. But when she displays a conceited attitude, he leaves without teaching. However, she corrects herself so he teaches her that pleasure and pain depend on the senses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

children: [{'uid': 'sn46.131-142', 'root_name': 'Punagaṅgāpeyyālavagga', 'translated_name': 'Another Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on the Ganges ', 'acronym': 'SN 46.131–142', 'blurb': None, 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'sn3.11', 'root_name': 'Sattajaṭilasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.11', 'blurb': 'A diverse group of ascetics passes by, and Pasenadi asks the Buddha if any of them are perfected ones. The Buddha says it is not easy for one such as Pasenadi to judge the spiritual achievements of others. Pasenadi reveals that the men are, in fact, his spies.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn3.12', 'root_name': 'Pañcarājasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.12', 'blurb': 'Five kings including Pasenadi are enjoying themselves and wonder which of the senses affords the highest pleasure. They ask the Buddha, who replies that it is subjective, depending on a persons preferences. Inspired, the laymen Candanaṅgalika offers a verse in praise of the Buddha.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn3.13', 'root_name': 'Doṇapākasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.13', 'blurb': 'In what is probably the world’s first weight loss diet, when Pasenadi shows up overweight and out of breath, the Buddha advises him to cut down his eating. He gives a verse to one of the king’s attendants, and asks him to recite it whenever the king is eating.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn3.14', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamasaṅgāmasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.14', 'blurb': 'Pasenadi loses a battle against his nephew King Ajātasattu of Magadha.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn3.15', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasaṅgāmasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.15', 'blurb': 'In a battle subsequent to SN 3.14, Pasenadi defeats Ajātasattu and takes him prisoner. Acting compassionately, he confiscates Ajātasattu’s military assets but releases him alive.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn3.16', 'root_name': 'Mallikāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 3.16', 'blurb': 'Pasenadi is disappointed to hear that Queen Mallikā has given birth to a daughter. children: [{'uid': 'sn12.21', 'root_name': 'Dasabalasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.21', 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.22', 'root_name': 'Dutiyadasabalasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.22', 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence. When hearing such an open teaching, a mendicant puts forth great effort, considering the good for both themselves and for others.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.23', 'root_name': 'Upanisasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.23', 'blurb': 'The ending of defilements comes only when the truth is seen. But seeing the truth comes about due to a vital condition. In this way, twelve factors leading to freedom are united with the twelve factors leading to suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.24', 'root_name': 'Aññatitthiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.24', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta is asked by various ascetics as to the origin of suffering. He replies that the Buddha teaches that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.25', 'root_name': 'Bhūmijasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.25', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta is asked by Venerable Bhūmija as to the origin of pleasure and pain. He replies that the Buddha teaches that pleasure and pain originate by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions on this question are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.26', 'root_name': 'Upavāṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.26', 'blurb': 'The Buddha is asked by Venerable Upavāṇa as to the origin of suffering. He replies that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.27', 'root_name': 'Paccayasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.27', 'blurb': 'Dependent origination is framed within the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.28', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhusutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.28', 'blurb': 'A mendicant who understands dependent origination is a trainee who is accomplished in view.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.29', 'root_name': 'Samaṇabrāhmaṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.29', 'blurb': 'An ascetic who understands dependent origination will realize the goal of the ascetic life.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn12.30', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 12.30', 'blurb': 'An ascetic who understands dependent origination may well escape those conditions.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The Paṭisambhidāmagga or “Path of Analytical Discernment” is an advanced critical treatise in thirty chapters on Buddhist practice, which the Pali commentaries attribute to the Buddha’s disciple Sāriputta. Departing from the popular or folksy style of most Khuddaka texts, it is more reminiscent of the Abhidhamma, and indeed, while not included in the Abhidhammapiṭaka, it deserves to be considered part of the Theravādin Abhidhamma system. However, it does not make use of the main Abhidhamma mātikās. This text introduces a number of terms and ideas of great importance in later Buddhist philosophy. It does not have any counterparts in the northern canons, but articulates a dictinctly Theravādin perspective on the path.

translated_name: When Kaccāni Made a Death-Offering to Dhamma
children: [{'uid': 'ja417', 'root_name': 'Kaccānijātaka', 'translated_name': 'When Kaccāni Made a Death-Offering to Dhamma ', 'acronym': 'Ja 417', 'blurb': '“Robed in white”—The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a man who supported his mother.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja418', 'root_name': 'Aṭṭhasaddajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Eight Sounds ', 'acronym': 'Ja 418', 'blurb': '“A pool so deep”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning an indistinguishable terrific sound heard at midnight by the king of Kosala. The occasion is like that already described in the Lohakumbhi Birth. At this time however, when the king said, “Lord, what does the hearing of these sounds import to me?” the Master answered, “Great king, be not afraid: no danger shall befal you owing to these sounds: such terrible indistinguishable sounds have not been heard by you alone: kings of old also heard like sounds, and meant to follow the advice of brahmins to offer in sacrifice four animals of each species, but after hearing what wise men had to say, they set free the animals collected for sacrifice and caused proclamation by drum against all slaughter”: and at the king’s request, he told the old tale.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja419', 'root_name': 'Sulasājātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Courtesan Sulasā ', 'acronym': 'Ja 419', 'blurb': '“Here is a golden necklace”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a female servant of Anathapindika.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja420', 'root_name': 'Sumaṅgalajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Park-Keeper Sumaṅgala ', 'acronym': 'Ja 420', 'blurb': '“Conscious of an angry frown”—The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the admonition of a king. On this occasion the Master, at the king’s request, told the tale of old.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja421', 'root_name': 'Gaṅgamālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Royal Barber Gaṅgamāla ', 'acronym': 'Ja 421', 'blurb': '“The earth’s like coals”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the keeping of the weekly holy days. One day the Master was addressing the lay-brethren who were keeping the holy days and said, “Lay-brethren, your conduct is good; when men keep the holy days they should give alms, keep the moral precepts, never show anger, feel kindness and do the duties of the day: wise men of old gained great glory from even a partial keeping of the holy days: “ and at their request he told the tale of old.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja422', 'root_name': 'Cetiyajātaka', 'translated_name': 'How the King of Ceti Told the First Lie ', 'acronym': 'Ja 422', 'blurb': '“Injured Right can injure sorely”—The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning Devadatta’s being swallowed up by the earth. On that day they were discussing in the Hall of Truth how Devadatta had spoken falsely, had sunk into the ground and become destined to the hell Avici. The Master came and, hearing the subject of their talk, said, “This is not the first time he sank into the earth,” and so he told the tale of old.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja423', 'root_name': 'Indriyajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Senses ', 'acronym': 'Ja 423', 'blurb': '“Who through desire”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning temptation by the wife of one’s former days.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja424', 'root_name': 'Ādittajātaka', 'translated_name': 'When Your House is Burning Down ', 'acronym': 'Ja 424', 'blurb': '“Whate’er a man can save”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning an incomparable gift. The incomparable gift must be described in full from the commentary on the Mahagovindasutta. On the day after that on which it had been given, they were talking of it in the Hall of Truth, “Sirs, the Kosala king after examination found the proper field of merit, and gave the great gift to the assembly with Buddha at its head.” The Master came and was told what the subject of their talk was as they sat together: he said, “Brethren, it is not strange that the king after examination has undertaken great gifts to the supreme field of merit: wise men of old also after examination gave such gifts,” and so he told a tale of old.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja425', 'root_name': 'Aṭṭhānajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Impossible ', 'acronym': 'Ja 425', 'blurb': '“Make Ganges calm”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a backsliding Brother. The Master asked him, “Is the story true, Brother, that you are backsliding?” “Yes, lord.” “What is the cause?” “The power of desire.” “Brother, womankind are ungrateful, treacherous, untrustworthy: of old wise men could not satisfy a woman, even by giving her a thousand pieces a day: and one day when she did not get the thousand pieces she had them taken by the neck and cast out: so ungrateful are womankind: do not fall into the power of desire for such a cause,” and so he told an old tale.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja426', 'root_name': 'Dīpijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Panther ', 'acronym': 'Ja 426', 'blurb': '“How fares it with you”—The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a certain she-goat.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Nuns” contains 10 discourses describing occasions when various nuns retreat to a forest for meditation, only to be challenged by Māra. The verses here partly overlap with the Therīgāthā, though there are some that are unique to this context, and we also have a prose narrative to flesh out the context. Māra’s challenges are various; sometimes he is sexist, alleging that women are weak in wisdom (SN 5.2). Several of these short texts are among the most frequently quoted of all the suttas.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Cloud Gods” is the last of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “cloud gods” or valāhakas, who are deities of the weather controlling the clouds.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Undeclared Points
children: [{'uid': 'sn44.1', 'root_name': 'Khemāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.1', 'blurb': 'While staying in Toraṇavatthu, King Pasenadi wishes to visit a spiritual teacher, and the nun Khemā is highly recommended to him. He asks her about whether a realized One exists after death, and she says this is not answerable. Later he visits the Buddha, who replies in exactly the same way.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.2', 'root_name': 'Anurādhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.2', 'blurb': 'Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that the Realized One is described in terms other than “existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a Realized One is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.3', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamasāriputtakoṭṭhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.3', 'blurb': 'Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that to answer this would be to get involved in the five aggregates, something that a Realized One is free from.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.4', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasāriputtakoṭṭhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.4', 'blurb': 'Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that one who understands the five aggregates would not think in such terms.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.5', 'root_name': 'Tatiyasāriputtakoṭṭhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.5', 'blurb': 'Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that only someone who has desire for the five aggregates would think in such terms.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.6', 'root_name': 'Catutthasāriputtakoṭṭhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.6', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta asks Mahākoṭṭhita whether a Realized One exists after death. Mahākoṭṭhita says that only someone who delights in the five aggregates would think in such terms, and offers a variety of further explanations of the same point.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.7', 'root_name': 'Moggallānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.7', 'blurb': 'The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Moggallāna the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. Moggallāna says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the six senses. Vacchagotta then asks the Buddha the same questions.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.8', 'root_name': 'Vacchagottasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.8', 'blurb': 'The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. He says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the five aggregates.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.9', 'root_name': 'Kutūhalasālāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.9', 'blurb': 'The wanderer Vacchagotta reports to the Buddha a conversation among ascetics on the views of the six heretical teachers as to where a perfected one is reborn. Unsure of what the Buddha’s position was, he asks how it is to be understood. The Buddha says it is like a flame that burns dependent on fuel, and goes out when that fuel is extinguished.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.10', 'root_name': 'Ānandasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.10', 'blurb': 'Vacchagotta asks the Buddha whether a self exists, but the Buddha is silent. When Ānanda later asks him why he didn’t answer, the Buddha replied that it was to avoid misunderstanding.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn44.11', 'root_name': 'Sabhiyakaccānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 44.11', 'blurb': 'The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna whether a Realized One exists after death. He answers that the basis for describing a Realized One no longer applies. Vacchagotta is impressed that such a junior monk understands this subtle matter.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Dragons” is the first of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “dragons” or nāgas, a powerful but morally ambiguous serpentine creature of the waterways.

blurb: Twelve poems beginning with a set of similes comparing a liberated one with a serpent who sheds its skin. The poems are diverse in style and content, and appear to have been collected from different sources. This chapter includes many perennial favorites such as the Mettā Sutta on Love and the warnings of the Parābhava Sutta on downfalls.
children: [{'uid': 'snp1.1', 'root_name': 'Uragasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Snake ', 'acronym': 'Snp 1.1', 'blurb': 'One who advances far along the path sloughs off the near shore and far, like a snake who sloughs off its skin.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'snp1.2', 'root_name': 'Dhaniyasutta', 'translated_name': 'With Dhaniya the Cowherd ', 'acronym': 'Snp 1.2', 'blurb': 'A poetic dialogue contrasting the wealth and security of lay life with the wealth and security of a person who has lived the renunciate life to its culmination. blurb: Collections of “linked” or “connected” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{'uid': 'sn', 'root_name': 'Saṁyuttanikāya', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses Collection ', 'acronym': 'SN', 'blurb': 'The “Linked” or “Connected” Discourses (Saṁyutta Nikāya, abbreviated SN) is a collection of over a thousand short discourses in the Pali canon. The word “linked” refers to the fact that the texts are collected and organized by topic. In most cases the organizing principle is a particular theme of Dhamma, for example, the five aggregates, dependent origination, the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation, or the four noble truths. This collection contains the most extensive range of texts on these core themes. In other cases chapters are organized according to the person or kind of person who speaks. This collection has a full parallel in the Saṁyuktāgama (SA) of the Sarvāstivāda school in Chinese translation. In addition, there are two partial collections in Chinese (SA-2 and SA-3) as well as a number of miscellaneous or fragmentary texts in Chinese, Sanskrit, and Tibetan. Much of the organizational structure of SN is shared with SA, suggesting that this structure preceded the split between these two collections.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2661}, {'uid': 'sa', 'root_name': 'Saṁyuktāgama (1st)', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses Compilation (1st) ', 'acronym': 'SA', 'blurb': 'The main version of the Linked Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Saṁyuktāgama (Za ahan jing, 雜阿含經), and is believed to stem from a branch of the Sarvāstivādin school. It was translated by Guṇabhadra (求那跋陀) and Baoyun (寶雲) in CE 435–436 at Waguan Monastery (瓦官寺,) Yangdu (楊都). Like the Pali Saṁyutta Nikāya, it contains over a thousand short suttas organized by topic. The texts, however, became disordered during the transmission in China, and an extraneous passage from a later life of Ashoka was mistakenly included. In the 20th century a series of scholars reconstructed the original sequence. The text as originally found is found in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon as sutra number 99 at T vol. 2, 1a.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'SA', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 402}, {'uid': 'sa-2', 'root_name': 'Saṁyuktāgama (2nd)', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses Compilation (2nd) ', 'acronym': 'SA 2', 'blurb': 'A partial translation of the Saṁyuktāgama (SA-2) was made between 385 and 431 by an anonymous translator. Known as the Shorter Saṁyuktāgama (Bieyi za ahan jing, 別譯雜阿含經), it may stem from the Mūlasarvāstivādin school. It consists of 364 sutras in 16 fascicles. Most of the texts have parallels in Chinese and/or Pali, primarily in the Sagāthāvagga of the Saṁyutta. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 100, located at T vol. 2, 374a.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'SA-2', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 62}, {'uid': 'sa-3', 'root_name': 'Saṁyuktāgama (3rd)', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses Compilation (3rd) ', 'acronym': 'SA 3', 'blurb': 'A second partial translation of the Saṁyuktāgama (SA-3) (雜阿含經) was made approximately CE 222–280 by an anonymous translator and consists of 27 sutras in one fascicle. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 101, located at T vol. 2, 493a.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'SA-3', 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'sa-ot', 'root_name': 'Other Saṁyukta Sūtras', 'translated_name': 'Other Linked Discourses ', 'acronym': 'Other SA', 'blurb': '22 shorter discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at sūtra numbers 102–124, following the three Saṁyuktāgama collections. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Saṁyutta, made at various times by various translators.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'SA ot', 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: Collections of “numbered” or “numerical” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{'uid': 'an', 'root_name': 'Aṅguttaranikāya', 'translated_name': 'Numbered Discourses Collection ', 'acronym': 'AN', 'blurb': "The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'AN', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1963}, {'uid': 'ea', 'root_name': 'Ekottarikāgama (1st)', 'translated_name': 'Numbered Discourses Compilation (1st) ', 'acronym': 'EA', 'blurb': 'The main version of the Numbered or Incremental Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Ekottarikāgama (Zengyi ahan jing, 增一阿含經), and has been tentatively ascribed to the Mahāsaṅghika school. It was translated by Gautama Saṅghadeva (瞿曇僧伽提婆), who also translated the Madhyamāgama, in CE 397. Consisting of 51 fascicles, it is organized into 52 chapters, containing a total of 451 sutras. Like the Pali Aṅguttara, it is arranged by numbered sets from one to eleven. However, despite the structural similarity, the contents diverge widely from the Pali. It contains relatively fewer parallels than the other āgama collections. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 125, located at T vol. 2, 549a.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'EA', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 150}, {'uid': 'ea-2', 'root_name': 'Ekottarikāgama (2nd)', 'translated_name': 'Numbered Discourses Compilation (2nd) ', 'acronym': 'EA 2 [T 150A]', 'blurb': 'A partial translation of the Ekottarikāgama was made by An Shigao (安世高 ) in CE 148–170. Known as Qi Chu San Guan Jing (七處三觀經), it consists of one fascicle containing 47 shorter sutras. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 150A, located at T vol. 2, 875b.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'EA-2', 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'ea-ot', 'root_name': 'Other Ekottarika Sūtras', 'translated_name': 'Other Numbered Discourses ', 'acronym': 'Other EA', 'blurb': '29 shorter discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at sūtra numbers 126–151, following the complete Ekottarikāgama collection. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Ekottara, made at various times by various translators.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': 'EA ot', 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}]

blurb: The Pali version of this famous text, consisting of 423 verses organized into memorable themes. It is the most widely read of the early texts, and has been translated many times into many languages. Versions of this text are found in Chinese, Tibetan, and several Indic languages, attesting to its timeless, universal appeal.

[{'uid': 'ja526', 'root_name': 'Niḷinikājātaka', 'translated_name': 'Princess Niḷinikā ', 'acronym': 'Ja 526', 'blurb': '“Lo! the land”—This story the Master told while residing at Jetavana concerning the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With the Aggregates
blurb: The “Book of the Aggregates” is the third of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest saṁyutta, which deals with the core Buddhist teaching of the five aggregates. Of the remaining twelve saṁyuttas, three also take up the theme of the aggregates, while the remainder deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.
children: [{'uid': 'sn22', 'root_name': 'Khandhasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on the Aggregates ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses on the Aggregates” contains 159 discourses on the core doctrinal topic of the five aggregates. This term was introduced in the first sermon as the summary of the noble truth of suffering, and became a foundational teaching in all forms of Buddhism. The basic idea of an “aggregate” is a set or class of phenomena. The five are form (rūpa, i.e. “physical phenomena”, or sometimes simply “body”; note that in Buddhism, rūpa includes all things with material properties such as shape and color, including visions perceived only in the mind), feeling (vedanā, i.e. the pleasant, painful, or neutral tone of experience), perception (saññā, i.e. the recognition or interpretation of experience, not sense awareness), choices (saṅkhārā, i.e. intention, will, or volition; the choice to perform an act, especially one with an ethical dimension), and consciousness (viññāṇa, i.e. the subjective process of awareness itself). The “aggregates” are the various different phenomena so classified. Almost always, they are referred to as the “aggregates connected with grasping” (upādānakkhandha). The relation between “grasping” and “aggregate” encompasses a number of aspects. The aggregates are the subject of grasping, in that they are the things that are normally attached to and taken to be the permanent “self”. But they are not merely passive spectators: they are also the functional support of grasping, the things that make grasping work. As active participants in the process of grasping, they stimulate grasping to themselves (upādāniya). And finally, they are the product of grasping in the sense that attachments in past lives have given rise to the aggregates in this life (upādinna). One of the key functions of the aggregates is to categorize theories of the self. From the discourses, non-Buddhists seem to be familiar with this, yet we cannot identify the aggregates in any pre-Buddhist texts. Regardless of whether the set of categories was pre-Buddhist, the Buddha treated them in his own distinctive way, emphasizing that nothing in the aggregates was a permanent self or soul. In this collection we find a large number of striking and lively narratives, showing how the aggregates could be a solace at the time of death, a guide to the knotty theoretical debates on identity, or a framework for insight meditation. Many of the short abbreviated texts are built from the same templates employed in the “Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields”.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 22', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 263}, {'uid': 'sn23', 'root_name': 'Rādhasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses with Rādha ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses with Rādha” contains 46 discourses with a monk named Rādha on the topic of the five aggregates, and may be considered as an appendix to the previous saṁyutta. ", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 23', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 26}, {'uid': 'sn24', 'root_name': 'Diṭṭhisaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Views ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses on Views” contains 96 discourses on views, methodically analyzed through the lens of the aggregates. A wide variety of views is assessed, most of which are familiar from elsewhere in the canon, although the first one is unique.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 24', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 35}, {'uid': 'sn25', 'root_name': 'Okkantasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Arrival at the Truth ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses on Arrival” is the first of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items (shared also with SN 18 Rāhula) and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that anyone who has these things will suffer.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 26', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 10}, {'uid': 'sn27', 'root_name': 'Kilesasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Corruptions ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses on Corruptions” is the third of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter is on the “fairies” or gandhabbas, who take on a number of benign aspects as minor deities associated with music, childbirth, and as here, plants.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 31', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 6}, {'uid': 'sn32', 'root_name': 'Valāhakasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Cloud Gods ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses on Cloud Gods” is the last of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “cloud gods” or valāhakas, who are deities of the weather controlling the clouds.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 32', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 9}, {'uid': 'sn33', 'root_name': 'Vacchagottasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses with Vacchagotta ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses with Vacchagotta” contains 55 discourses, each with a philosophical inquiry by the wanderer Vacchagotta. These do not exhaust his questions; he also appears in a number of other discourses, notably MN 71–73, where he resolves his doubts and becomes perfected. The current chapter shows him repeatedly raising the question of the ten speculative views, and why they appear. The discourses are entirely formulaic and appear to have been produced from a template. Unusually for a section of this length, it lacks vaggas.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 33', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 16}, {'uid': 'sn34', 'root_name': 'Jhānasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Absorption ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses on Absorption” (Jhānasaṁyutta) is also known as the “Linked Discourses on Immersion” (Samādhisaṁyutta). It contains 55 discourses dealing with the meditative skills required to perfect absorption. Each discourse describes a meditator who is skilled in some aspects, but not in others, and holds the one skilled in all aspects to be the best.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 34', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 27}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Absorption” (Jhānasaṁyutta) is also known as the “Linked Discourses on Immersion” (Samādhisaṁyutta). It contains 55 discourses dealing with the meditative skills required to perfect absorption. Each discourse describes a meditator who is skilled in some aspects, but not in others, and holds the one skilled in all aspects to be the best.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Females” contains 34 discourses regarding various qualities of women. Note that the Pali texts use two distinct terms for women, itthī and mātugāma, the latter of which can be translated as “females”. These texts deal with such themes as the kinds of suffering unique to women, why women are reborn in various states, or the qualities that lead to a woman taking charge in her marriage.

translated_name: The Chapter in a Rosewood Forest
children: [{'uid': 'sn56.31', 'root_name': 'Sīsapāvanasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.31', 'blurb': 'In a siṁsapā grove, the Buddha holds up a handful of leaves, and compares it to all the leaves in the forest. So too, he has taught the four noble truths, which is only a fraction of what he knows.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.32', 'root_name': 'Khadirapattasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.32', 'blurb': 'Just as it’s impossible to keep water in a basket of pine needles, it’s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.33', 'root_name': 'Daṇḍasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.33', 'blurb': 'Beings who have not seen the four noble truths roam on from one birth to another, like a stick thrown end to end. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.34', 'root_name': 'Celasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.34', 'blurb': 'Even more than if your clothes are on fire, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.35', 'root_name': 'Sattisatasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.35', 'blurb': 'Even more than if you’re being tortured with spikes, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.36', 'root_name': 'Pāṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.36', 'blurb': 'The small creatures in the ocean are greater in number than all the foliage in the jungles of India. Still, your rebirths are more than this.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.37', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamasūriyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.37', 'blurb': 'As the dawn precedes the sunrise, right view precedes the penetration of the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.38', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasūriyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.38', 'blurb': 'As long as there are no sun and moon, the world is in darkness. So too, as long as the Realized One has not arisen and declared the four noble truths, the world is in darkness.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.39', 'root_name': 'Indakhīlasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.39', 'blurb': 'One who has not seen the four noble truths is as feeble as a tuft of cotton wool, while one who has seen them is like a deep-rooted pillar.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn56.40', 'root_name': 'Vādatthikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 56.40', 'blurb': 'No-one can refute you if you are well grounded in the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

children: [{'uid': 'sn24.19', 'root_name': 'Vātasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 24.19', 'blurb': 'The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn24.20-35', 'root_name': 'Etaṁmamādisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 24.20–35', 'blurb': 'The various views arise from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. [{'uid': 'ja181', 'root_name': 'Asadisajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Prince Peerless ', 'acronym': 'Ja 181', 'blurb': '“Prince Peerless, skilled in archers’ craft”—This story the Master told at Jetavana, about the Great Renunciation. The Master said, “Not now alone, Brethren, has the Tathagata made the Great Renunciation: in other days he also renounced the white parasol of royalty, and did the same.” And he told a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja182', 'root_name': 'Saṅgāmāvacarajātaka', 'translated_name': 'At Home in Battle ', 'acronym': 'Ja 182', 'blurb': '“O Elephant, a hero thou”—This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about Elder Nanda.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja183', 'root_name': 'Vālodakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Nasty Drink ', 'acronym': 'Ja 183', 'blurb': '“This sorry draught”—This story the Master told whilst at Jetavana, about five hundred persons who ate broken meat.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja184', 'root_name': 'Giridattajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Groom Giridatta ', 'acronym': 'Ja 184', 'blurb': '“Thanks to the groom”—This story the Master told while staying in Veluvana Park, about keeping bad company. The circumstances have been already recounted under the Mahilamukha Jataka. Again, as before, the Master said: “In former days this Brother kept bad company just as he does now.” Then he told an old story.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja185', 'root_name': 'Anabhiratijātaka', 'translated_name': 'Dissatsfaction ', 'acronym': 'Ja 185', 'blurb': '“Thick, muddy water”—This story the Master told while staying in Jetavana, and it was about a young brahmin.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja186', 'root_name': 'Dadhivāhanajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The King Carried on Curds ', 'acronym': 'Ja 186', 'blurb': '“Sweet was once the mango’s savour”—This story the Master told whilst dwelling in Jetavana, on the subject of keeping bad company. The circumstances were the same as above. Again the Master said: “Brethren, bad company is evil and injurious; why should one talk of the evil effects of had company on human beings? In days long gone by, even a vegetable, a mango tree, whose sweet fruit was a dish fit for the gods, turned sour and bitter through the influence of a noisome and bitter nimb tree.” Then he told a story.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja187', 'root_name': 'Catumaṭṭhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Polished in Four Ways ', 'acronym': 'Ja 187', 'blurb': '“Sit and sing”—This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about an old Brother.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja188', 'root_name': 'Sīhakotthujātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Lion-Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 188', 'blurb': '“Lion’s claws and lion’s paws”—This is a story told by the Master whilst at Jetavana, about Kokalika.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja189', 'root_name': 'Sīhacammajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal Wearing Lionskin ', 'acronym': 'Ja 189', 'blurb': '“Nor lion, nor tiger I see”—This story, like the last, was about Kokalika, told by the Master in Jetavana. This time he wanted to intone. The Master. on hearing of it told the following story.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja190', 'root_name': 'Sīlānisaṁsajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Benefits of Morality ', 'acronym': 'Ja 190', 'blurb': '“Behold the fruit of sacrifice”—This story the Master told whilst staying in Jetavana, about a believing layman.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: Collections of sutta texts outside the four main collections.
children: [{'uid': 'kn', 'root_name': 'Khuddakanikāya', 'translated_name': 'Minor Collection ', 'acronym': 'KN', 'blurb': "The word khuddaka means “lesser” or “minor”, and it seems that this category originally served to collect certain short collections, mostly verse, that were not conveniently assigned to one of the main nikāyas. Over time, however, the collection grew, so that the Khuddaka in the Pali canon today is the largest of the nikāyas. It includes some of the most popular texts in Theravāda Buddhism, such as the Dhammapada, the Sutta Nipāta, and the Jātakas. There is no closely parallel collection in the other canons, but many of the early texts have parallels in various places.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'KN', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2923}, {'uid': 'dharmapadas', 'root_name': 'Dharmapadas', 'translated_name': 'Various Dharmapada Texts ', 'acronym': 'Dhp', 'blurb': 'Verse collections that are similar to the Dhammapada of the Pali Khuddhaka Nikāya.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': None, 'root_lang_name': None, 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 243}, {'uid': 'minor-lzh', 'root_name': 'Minor Chinese', 'translated_name': 'Minor Chinese Texts ', 'acronym': 'Minor Lzh', 'blurb': 'Miscellanous texts relating to the early scriptures. These are mostly Chinese translations of texts similar to those found in the Pali canon', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 78}]

blurb: This portion of the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon is simply called “miscellaneous collection” ( 經集部), and it includes sūtra texts that are not readily classifiable elsewhere. While the section is mostly for Mahāyāna sūtras, a number of parallels with early discourses have been identified.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Vacchagotta” contains 55 discourses, each with a philosophical inquiry by the wanderer Vacchagotta. These do not exhaust his questions; he also appears in a number of other discourses, notably MN 71–73, where he resolves his doubts and becomes perfected. The current chapter shows him repeatedly raising the question of the ten speculative views, and why they appear. The discourses are entirely formulaic and appear to have been produced from a template. Unusually for a section of this length, it lacks vaggas.

blurb: The main version of the Numbered or Incremental Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Ekottarikāgama (Zengyi ahan jing, 增一阿含經), and has been tentatively ascribed to the Mahāsaṅghika school. It was translated by Gautama Saṅghadeva (瞿曇僧伽提婆), who also translated the Madhyamāgama, in CE 397. Consisting of 51 fascicles, it is organized into 52 chapters, containing a total of 451 sutras. Like the Pali Aṅguttara, it is arranged by numbered sets from one to eleven. However, despite the structural similarity, the contents diverge widely from the Pali. It contains relatively fewer parallels than the other āgama collections. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 125, located at T vol. 2, 549a.

One day it happened that the Brethren were talking in the Hall of Truth about Devadatta’s ingratitude and treachery to his friends, when the Master broke in, “Not this once only, Brethren, has Devadatta been ungrateful and treacherous to his own friends. [{'uid': 'sn22.53', 'root_name': 'Upayasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.53', 'blurb': 'Consciousness stands dependent on the other four aggregates, and this attachment is what fuels the cycle of rebirth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.54', 'root_name': 'Bījasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.54', 'blurb': 'Consciousness is like a seed that is planted in the soil of the other four aggregates and watered with craving.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.55', 'root_name': 'Udānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.55', 'blurb': 'The Buddha utters an enigmatic saying that non-identification leads to cutting off the fetters. A mendicant asks how to achieve this.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.56', 'root_name': 'Upādānaparipavattasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.56', 'blurb': 'The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood each of the five aggregates in the light of each of the four noble truths. This discourse includes definitions of each of the aggregates.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.57', 'root_name': 'Sattaṭṭhānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.57', 'blurb': 'To be fully accomplished, a mendicant should investigate the five aggregates in light of the four noble truths, as well as their gratification, drawback, and escape. In addition, they should investigate the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.58', 'root_name': 'Sammāsambuddhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.58', 'blurb': 'The Buddha declares that a mendicant is freed by wisdom by non-attachment to the aggregates, in just the same way as he himself. He then explains that the difference between himself and another awakened mendicant is simply that he was the first to discover the path and teach it to others.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.59', 'root_name': 'Anattalakkhaṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.59', 'blurb': 'In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.60', 'root_name': 'Mahālisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.60', 'blurb': 'Mahāli the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher Pūraṇa Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.61', 'root_name': 'Ādittasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.61', 'blurb': 'The five aggregates are burning.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn22.62', 'root_name': 'Niruttipathasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 22.62', 'blurb': 'All philosophers must accept that the five aggregates are described in language that refers to either the past, future, or present.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Fairies” is the third of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “fairies” or gandhabbas, who take on a number of benign aspects as minor deities associated with music, childbirth, and as here, plants.
