children: [{'uid': 'dhp', 'root_name': 'Dhammapada', 'translated_name': 'Sayings of the Dhamma ', 'acronym': 'Dhp', 'blurb': 'The Pali version of this famous text, consisting of 423 verses organized into memorable themes. It is the most widely read of the early texts, and has been translated many times into many languages. Versions of this text are found in Chinese, Tibetan, and several Indic languages, attesting to its timeless, universal appeal.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 123}, {'uid': 'uv', 'root_name': 'Udānavarga', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings ', 'acronym': 'Uv', 'blurb': 'The Udānavarga or “Collection of Inspired Sayings” is a Sarvāstivādin Dhammapada-style text. At 1044 verses, it is over twice as long as the Pali Dhammapada, and the longest of all the Dhammapadas. The manuscript was among the Sanskrit texts discovered at Turfan. The SuttaCentral text is sourced from the Titus edition prepared by Gippert and Kupfer, and based on the edition by Bernhard (1965). There are Chinese and Tibetan translations of this text.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'uvs', 'root_name': 'Udānavarga de Subaši', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Subaši edition) ', 'acronym': 'UvS', 'blurb': 'A critical edition by H. Nakatani of the Sanskrit manuscript on wood from Subaši, Bibliothèque nationale de Paris, Pelliot Collection, 1987–1988.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'san', 'root_lang_name': 'Sanskrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'pdhp', 'root_name': 'Patna Dharmapada', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Patna) ', 'acronym': 'P-Dhp', 'blurb': 'The Patna Dharmapada is based on a manuscript discovered in Tibet by Rāhula Saṅkṛtyāyana in 1934, written in proto-Bengali script, and dated around the twelfth century. It is in a distinct variety of Sanskritized Prākrit, and has been identified by Skilling and Mizuno as belonging to the Sāmmatīya school. The SuttaCentral text is based on the edition by Margaret Cone (1989), digitized by Ānandajoti.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pra', 'root_lang_name': 'Prākrit', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 22}, {'uid': 'gdhp', 'root_name': 'Gāndhārī Dharmapada', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Gāndhārī, 1st) ', 'acronym': 'G Dhp', 'blurb': 'The Gāndhārī Dharmapada (also known as the Khotan Dhammapada) is from a birch-bark manuscript in Kharoṣṭhī script discovered at Kohmāri Mazār near Khotan in Xinjiang in 1892. It dates to the early centuries CE, and is one of the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts. It was edited and published by Brough (1962), and was digitized by Gandhari.org.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pgd', 'root_lang_name': 'Gāndhārī', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'g2dhp', 'root_name': 'Gāndhārī 2nd Dharmapada', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Gāndhārī, 2nd) ', 'acronym': 'G-2 Dhp', 'blurb': 'Fragments of a Dhammapada in Gāndhārī', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pgd', 'root_lang_name': 'Gāndhārī', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'g3dhp', 'root_name': 'Gāndhārī 3rd Dharmapada', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Gāndhārī, 3rd) ', 'acronym': 'G-3 Dhp', 'blurb': 'Fragments of another Dhammapada in Gāndhārī', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pgd', 'root_lang_name': 'Gāndhārī', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 't210', 'root_name': '法句經 (T 210)', 'translated_name': 'Sayings of the Dharma (Chinese) ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dhp 1', 'blurb': 'Two fascicles compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救, T 210.4.559–574. It was brought by the Indian monk Vighna 維祇難 to Wuchang 武昌, China in 224 C.E., and translated by Zhu Jiangyan 竺將炎 and Zhi Qian 支謙. It is a collection of verses comprising the basic teachings of Buddhism which is similar to the Pali Dhammapada. The Chinese version contains 758 verses. There are four Chinese translations, dated CE 224, 290–306, 399, and 980–1001.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 26}, {'uid': 't211', 'root_name': '法句譬喻經 (T 211)', 'translated_name': 'Sayings of the Dharma With Stories (Chinese) ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dhp 2', 'blurb': 'Four fascicles, compiled by Dharmatrāta and translated by Faju 法炬, and Fali 法立 during the years of Huidi 惠帝 (290–306 C.E.) in the Western Jin dynasty 西晉 at Luoyang. Also known by the titles of 法句本末經, 法句喩經, 法喩經, and 法句譬經. Written in thirty-nine chapters, it is, like the 法句經 (T 210), closely related to the Dhammapada of the Pāli Canon, and about two thirds of this text are the same as T 210. It is composed of explanatory text added to the verses of the Dharmapāda.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 39}, {'uid': 't212', 'root_name': '出曜經 (T 212)', 'translated_name': 'The Appearance of Light ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dhp 3', 'blurb': "The Indian original text compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救 consisted of 33 chapters and about 1000 verses, and it was translated by Saṃghabhadra 僧伽跋澄 and Zhu Fonian 竺佛念 during 398–399. The present T 212 has 34 chapters, and its chapters correspond to the present Udānavarga, which has 33 chapters and 1050 verses, except that it has two separated chapters, i.e. the chapter of non-carelessness 無放逸品 and the chapter of carelessness 放逸品, for the chapter 'Apramādavarga' of the Udānavarga. Like T 211, this text also provides the verses along with the background stories in prose. When the verses are same with those of T 210, the translators of T 211 followed the translation of T 210 rather than did a new translation.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 't213', 'root_name': '法集要頌經 (T 213)', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Chinese) ', 'acronym': 'Lzh Dhp 4', 'blurb': 'Also attributed to Dharmatrāta’s compilation, this was translated by Tianxizai 天息災 (?–1000), who arrived at the capital of Song dynasty in 980. It has 33 chapters corresponding to the chapters of the Udānavarga, but, unlike T 212, this text has only verses without commentaries. The translator of T 213 followed the translation of T 212, and he also followed the translation of T 210 when those verses are not in T 212 but same with T 210.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': False, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 0}, {'uid': 'uv-kg', 'root_name': 'ཆེད་དུ་བརྗོད་པའི་ཚོམས་', 'translated_name': 'Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Tibetan) ', 'acronym': 'Uv Kg', 'blurb': 'A Tibetan translation of the Udānavarga, attributed to Dharmatrāta. There is a commentary on this text by Prajñāvarman.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'lzh', 'root_lang_name': 'Chinese', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 33}]

[{'uid': 'ja71', 'root_name': 'Varuṇajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Temple Tree ', 'acronym': 'Ja 71', 'blurb': '“Learn thou from him.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder named Tissa the Squire’s Son. Tradition says that one day thirty young gentlemen of Savatthi, who were all friends of one another, took perfumes and flowers and robes, and set out with a large retinue to Jetavana, in order to hear the Master preach. Arrived at Jetavana, they sat awhile in the several enclosures—in the enclosure of the Iron-wood trees, in the enclosure of the Sal-trees, and so forth,—till at evening the Master passed from his fragrant sweet-smelling perfumed chamber to the Hall of Truth and took his seat on the gorgeous Buddha-seat. Then, with their following, these young men went to the Hall of Truth, made an offering of perfumes and flowers, bowed down at his feet—those blessed feet that were glorious as full-blown lotus-flowers, and bore imprinted on the sole the Wheel!—and, taking their seats, listened to the Truth. Then the thought came into their minds, “Let us take the vows, so far as we understand the Truth preached by the Master.” Accordingly, when the Blessed One left the Hall, they approached him and with due obeisance asked to be admitted to the Brotherhood; and the Master admitted them to the Brotherhood. Winning the favour of their teachers and directors they received full Brotherhood, and after five years’ residence with their teachers and directors, by which time they had got by heart the two Abstracts, had come to know what was proper and what was improper, had learnt the three modes of expressing thanks, and had stitched and dyed robes. At this stage, wishing to embrace the ascetic life, they obtained the consent of their teachers and directors, and approached the Master. Bowing before him they took their seats, saying, “Sir, we are troubled by the round of existence, dismayed by birth, decay, disease, and death; give us a theme, by thinking on which we may get free from the elements which occasion existence.” The Master turned over in his mind the eight and thirty themes of thought, and therefrom selected a suitable one, which he expounded to them. And then, after getting their theme from the Master, they bowed and with a ceremonious farewell passed from his presence to their cells, and after gazing on their teachers and directors went forth with bowl and robe to embrace the ascetic life.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja72', 'root_name': 'Sīlavahatthijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Virtuous Elephant King ', 'acronym': 'Ja 72', 'blurb': '“Ingratitude lacks more.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about Devadatta. The Brethren sat in the Hall of Truth, saying, “Sirs, Devadatta is an ingrate and does not recognise the virtues of the Blessed One.” Returning to the Hall, the Master asked what topic they were discussing, and was told. “This is not the first time, Brethren,” said he, “that Devadatta has proved an ingrate; he was just the same in bygone days also, and he has never known my virtues.” And so saying, at their request he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja73', 'root_name': 'Saccaṁkirajātaka', 'translated_name': 'It Seems They Knew the Truth ', 'acronym': 'Ja 73', 'blurb': '“They knew the world.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about going about to kill. For, seated in the Hall of Truth, the Brotherhood was talking of Devadatta’s wickedness, saying, “Sirs, Devadatta has no knowledge of the Master’s excellence; he actually goes about to kill him!” Here the Master entered the Hall and asked what they were discussing. 323] Being told, he said, “This is not the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta has gone about to kill me; he did just the same in bygone days also.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja74', 'root_name': 'Rukkhadhammajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Lesson of the Tree ', 'acronym': 'Ja 74', 'blurb': '“United, forest-like.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a quarrel concerning water which had brought woe upon his kinsfolk. Knowing of this, he passed through the air, sat cross-legged above the river Rohini, and emitted rays of darkness, startling his kinsfolk. Then descending from mid-air, he seated himself on the river-bank and told this story with reference to that quarrel. (Only a summary is given here; the full details will be related in the Kunala-jataka.) But on this occasion the Master addressed his kinsfolk, saying, “It is meet, sire, that kinsfolk should dwell together in concord and unity. For, when kinsfolk are at one, enemies find no opportunity. Not to speak of human beings, even sense-lacking trees ought to stand together. For in bygone days in the Himalayas a tempest struck a Sal-forest; yet, because the trees, shrubs, bushes, and creepers of that forest were interlaced one with another, the tempest could not overthrow even a single tree but passed harmlessly over their heads. But alone in a courtyard stood a mighty tree; and though it had many stems and branches, yet, because it was not united with other trees, the tempest uprooted it and laid it low. Wherefore, it is meet that you too should dwell together in concord and unity.” And so saying, at their request he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja75', 'root_name': 'Macchajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Fish ', 'acronym': 'Ja 75', 'blurb': '“Pajjunna, thunder!”—This story the Master told while at Jetavana, about the rain he caused to fall. For in those days, so it is said, there fell no rain in Kosala; the crops withered; and everywhere the ponds, tanks, and lakes dried up. Even the pool of Jetavana by the embattled gateway of Jetavana gave out; and the fish and tortoises buried themselves in the mud. Then came the crows and hawks with their lance-like beaks, and busily picked them out writhing and wriggling, and devoured them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja76', 'root_name': 'Asaṁkiyajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Fearlessness ', 'acronym': 'Ja 76', 'blurb': '“The village breeds no fear in me.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-brother who lived at Savatthi. Tradition says that this man, who had entered the Paths and was an earnest believer, was once journeying along on some business or other in the company of a leader of a caravan; in the jungle the carts were unyoked and a laager was constructed; and the good man began to pace up and down at the foot of a certain tree hard by the leader.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja77', 'root_name': 'Mahāsupinajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Great Dreams ', 'acronym': 'Ja 77', 'blurb': '“Bulls first, and trees.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about sixteen wonderful dreams. For in the last watch of one night (so tradition says) the King of Kosala, who had been asleep all the night, dreamed sixteen great dreams, and woke up in great fright and alarm as to what they might portend for him. So strong was the fear of death upon him that he could not stir, but lay there huddled up on his bed. Now, when the night grew light, his brahmins and chaplains came to him and with due obeisance asked whether his majesty had slept well.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja78', 'root_name': 'Illisajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Two Illisas ', 'acronym': 'Ja 78', 'blurb': '“Both squint.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a miserly Lord High Treasurer. Hard by the city of Rajagaha, as we are told, was a town named Jagghery, and here dwelt a certain Lord High Treasurer, known as the Millionaire Miser, who was worth eighty crores! Not so much as the tiniest drop of oil that a blade of grass will take up, did he either give away or consume for his own enjoyment. So he made no use of all his wealth either for his family or for sages and brahmins: it remained unenjoyed,—like a pool haunted by demons. Now, it fell out on a day that the Master arose at dawn moved with a great compassion, and as he reviewed those ripe for conversion throughout the universe, he became aware that this Treasurer with his wife some four hundred miles away were destined to tread the Paths of Salvation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja79', 'root_name': 'Kharassarajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Harsh Drum ', 'acronym': 'Ja 79', 'blurb': '“He gave the robbers time.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain Minister. He, ’Tis said, ingratiated himself with the king, and, after collecting the royal revenue in a border-village, privily arranged with a band of robbers that he would march the men off into the jungle, leaving the village for the rascals to plunder,—on condition that they gave him half the booty. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja80', 'root_name': 'Bhīmasenajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Weaver Bhīmasena ', 'acronym': 'Ja 80', 'blurb': '“You vaunted your prowess.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain braggart among the Brethren. Tradition says that he used to gather round him Brethren of all ages, and go about deluding everyone with lying boasts about his noble descent. “Ah, Brethren,” he would say, “there’s no family so noble as mine, no lineage so peerless. I am a scion of the highest of princely lines; no man is my equal in birth or ancestral estate; there is absolutely no end to the gold and silver and other treasures we possess. Our very slaves and menials are fed on rice and meat-stews, and are clad in the best Benares cloth, with the choicest Benares perfumes to perfume themselves withal; whilst I, because I have joined the Brotherhood, [3561 have to content myself with this vile fare and this vile garb.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: The Buddhavaṁsa is a late devotional text in verse detailing the lives of 24 past Buddhas and the prediction of the awakening of the historical Buddha Gotama. This is a late text, without direct counterparts in the northern collections. It is, however, part of an extensive pan-sectarian devotional literature composed in the second and first centuries BCE, presaging the birth of the Mahāyāna.

translated_name: A Hundred Legends of Past Lives
blurb: The “Hundred Stories” is a popular collection of legends, associated with the Sarvāstivādins, and dating to the first centuries CE. A number of manuscript sources for the text are found, but the oldest complete manuscript and the primary source for modern editions is a Nepalese manuscript dated 1645 and held at the Cambridge University Library. While the text is quite late, it contains a few parallels with early texts. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, which was input by Klaus Wille based on the editions by Vaidya (1958) and Speyer (1906, 1909).

[{'uid': 'ja111', 'root_name': 'Gadrabhapañhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Question for a Donkey ', 'acronym': 'Ja 111', 'blurb': '“Thou think’st thyself a swan.”—This Question as to the Ass will also be set out at length in the Ummagga-jataka. This is the end of the Question as to the Ass.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja112', 'root_name': 'Amarādevīpañhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Question of Queen Ambrosia ', 'acronym': 'Ja 112', 'blurb': '“Cakes and gruel.”—This question too will be found in the same Jataka. This is the end of the Question of Queen Amara.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja113', 'root_name': 'Siṅgālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 113', 'blurb': '“The drunken jackal.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta. The Brethren had assembled in the Hall of Truth and were telling how Devadatta had gone to Gayasisa with five hundred followers, whom he was leading into error by declaring that the Truth was manifest in him “and not in the ascetic Gotama”; and how by his lies he was breaking up the Brotherhood; and how he kept two fast-days a week. And as they sate there talking of the wickedness of Devadatta, the Master entered and was told the subject of their conversation. “Brethren,” said he, “Devadatta was as great a liar in past times as he is now.” So saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja114', 'root_name': 'Mitacintijātaka', 'translated_name': 'Thoughtful ', 'acronym': 'Ja 114', 'blurb': '“They twain in fisher’s net.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about two aged Elders. After a rainy-season spent in a forest in the country they resolved to seek out the Master, and got together provisions for their journey. But they kept putting off their departure day by day, till a month flew by. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja115', 'root_name': 'Anusāsikajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Warner ', 'acronym': 'Ja 115', 'blurb': '“The greed-denouncing bird.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Sister who gave a warning to others. For we are told that she came of a good Savatthi family, but that from the day of her entrance into the Order she failed of her duty and was filled with a gluttonous spirit; she used to seek alms in quarters of the city unvisited by other Sisters. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja116', 'root_name': 'Dubbacajātaka', 'translated_name': 'An Unadmonishable Mendicant ', 'acronym': 'Ja 116', 'blurb': '“Too much.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about an unruly Brother whose-own story will be given in the Ninth Book in the Gijjha-jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja117', 'root_name': 'Tittirajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Partridge ', 'acronym': 'Ja 117', 'blurb': '“As died the partridge.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about Kokalika, whose story will be found in the Thirteenth Book in the Takkariya Jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja118', 'root_name': 'Vaṭṭakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Quail ', 'acronym': 'Ja 118', 'blurb': '“The thoughtless man.”—This story the Master told while at Jetavana, about the son of Over-Treasurer. This Over-Treasurer is said to have been a very rich man of Savatthi, and his wife became the mother of a righteous being from the realm of Brahma angels, who grew up as lovely as Brahma. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja119', 'root_name': 'Akālarāvijātaka', 'translated_name': 'Noisy at the Wrong Time ', 'acronym': 'Ja 119', 'blurb': '“No parents trained.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who used to be noisy at wrong seasons. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja120', 'root_name': 'Bandhanamokkhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Release From Bonds ', 'acronym': 'Ja 120', 'blurb': '“Whilst folly’s speech”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the brahmin-girl Cinca, whose history will be given in the Twelfth Book in the Mahapaduma-jataka. On this occasion the Master said, “Brethren, this is not the first time Cinca has laid false accusations against me. She did the like in other times.” So saying he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'sn4.21', 'root_name': 'Sambahulasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 4.21', 'blurb': 'Māra approaches some young mendicants as an old brahmin, and tries to tempt them with talk of the pleasures of youth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn4.22', 'root_name': 'Samiddhisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 4.22', 'blurb': 'Māra repeatedly pesters the monk Samiddhi when he is on retreat. The Buddha encourages him, until eventually Samiddhi is able to recognize Māra for himself.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn4.23', 'root_name': 'Godhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 4.23', 'blurb': 'Venerable Godhika finds himself repeatedly falling away from his meditation attainments due to severe illness. Eventually he considers suicide, and Māra tries to get the Buddha to deter him. But the Buddha says Godhika has already attained awakening and has died blamelessly.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn4.24', 'root_name': 'Sattavassānubandhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 4.24', 'blurb': 'Māra has tried to distract the Buddha for seven years without success. He laments his failure with the similes of a crab whose limbs are smashed by a group of children, and a crow who tried to eat a stone.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn4.25', 'root_name': 'Māradhītusutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 4.25', 'blurb': 'Depressed, Māra laments to his three daughters of his failure to distract the Buddha. So they take on the task themselves, and assume a variety of sensuous forms to tempt him. But they fail too, and Māra castigates them for being so presumptuous', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Unconditioned” contains 44 discourses on the theme of the unconditioned, i.e. nibbāna or “extinguishment”. They focus on the various practices that lead to the unconditioned. This chapter includes an extensive range of terms and idioms describing the final goal of Buddhist practice.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Lion’s Roar
blurb: Beginning with two discourses containing a “lion’s roar”, this chapter deals with suffering, community life, and practical meditation advice.
children: [{'uid': 'mn11', 'root_name': 'Cūḷasīhanādasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar ', 'acronym': 'MN 11', 'blurb': 'The Buddha declares that only those following his path can genuinely experience the four stages of awakening. This is because, while much is shared with other systems, none of them go so far as to fully reject all attachment to the idea of a self.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn12', 'root_name': 'Mahāsīhanādasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar ', 'acronym': 'MN 12', 'blurb': 'A disrobed monk, Sunakkhatta, attacks the Buddha’s teaching because it merely leads to the end of suffering. The Buddha counters that this is, in fact, praise, and goes on to enumerate his many profound and powerful achievements.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn13', 'root_name': 'Mahādukkhakkhandhasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering ', 'acronym': 'MN 13', 'blurb': 'Challenged to show the difference between his teaching and that of other ascetics, the Buddha points out that they speak of letting go, but do not really understand why. He then explains in great detail the suffering that arises from attachment to sensual stimulation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn14', 'root_name': 'Cūḷadukkhakkhandhasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering ', 'acronym': 'MN 14', 'blurb': 'A lay person is puzzled at how, despite their long practice, they still have greedy or hateful thoughts. The Buddha explains the importance of absorption meditation for letting go such attachments. But he also criticizes self-mortification, and recounts a previous dialog with Jain ascetics.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn15', 'root_name': 'Anumānasutta', 'translated_name': 'Measuring Up ', 'acronym': 'MN 15', 'blurb': 'Venerable Moggallāna raises the topic of admonishment, without which healthy community is not possible. He lists a number of qualities that will encourage others to think it worthwhile to admonish you in a constructive way.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn16', 'root_name': 'Cetokhilasutta', 'translated_name': 'Emotional Barrenness ', 'acronym': 'MN 16', 'blurb': 'The Buddha explains various ways one can become emotionally cut off from one’s spiritual community.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn17', 'root_name': 'Vanapatthasutta', 'translated_name': 'Jungle Thickets ', 'acronym': 'MN 17', 'blurb': 'While living in the wilderness is great, not everyone is ready for it. The Buddha encourages meditators to reflect on whether one’s environment is genuinely supporting their meditation practice, and if not, to leave.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn18', 'root_name': 'Madhupiṇḍikasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Honey-Cake ', 'acronym': 'MN 18', 'blurb': 'Challenged by a brahmin, the Buddha gives an enigmatic response on how conflict arises due to proliferation based on perceptions. Venerable Kaccāna draws out the detailed implications of this in one of the most insightful passages in the entire canon.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn19', 'root_name': 'Dvedhāvitakkasutta', 'translated_name': 'Two Kinds of Thought ', 'acronym': 'MN 19', 'blurb': 'Recounting his own experiences in developing meditation, the Buddha explains how to understand harmful and harmless thoughts, and how to go beyond thought altogether.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn20', 'root_name': 'Vitakkasaṇṭhānasutta', 'translated_name': 'How to Stop Thinking ', 'acronym': 'MN 20', 'blurb': 'In a practical meditation teaching, the Buddha describes five different approaches to stopping thoughts.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Arising” is the second of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that anyone who has these things will suffer.

blurb: The Indian original text compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救 consisted of 33 chapters and about 1000 verses, and it was translated by Saṃghabhadra 僧伽跋澄 and Zhu Fonian 竺佛念 during 398–399. The present T 212 has 34 chapters, and its chapters correspond to the present Udānavarga, which has 33 chapters and 1050 verses, except that it has two separated chapters, i.e. the chapter of non-carelessness 無放逸品 and the chapter of carelessness 放逸品, for the chapter 'Apramādavarga' of the Udānavarga. Like T 211, this text also provides the verses along with the background stories in prose. When the verses are same with those of T 210, the translators of T 211 followed the translation of T 210 rather than did a new translation.

translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses With Verses
blurb: The “Book With Verses” is the first of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is divided into eleven saṁyuttas or “sections”, with a total of 271 suttas. Most of these are further subdivided into vaggas of ten suttas. The word vagga is thus used of both the major overarching “book” and the subsidiary “chapter”. Each of the suttas in this collection contains verse with a prose narrative structure, although in many cases the prose has been omitted through abbreviation. Where most of the Saṁyutta is organized around subject matter, here the organizational principle is people. Each saṁyutta contains conversation involving the Buddha or his disciples with a different person or kind of person, such as gods, kings, nuns, or brahmins. A typical sutta has a bare narrative framework, where someone comes to the Buddha and utters a verse, and the Buddha replies with a better one. In some cases, notably the Sakkasaṁyutta, the narrative element is developed into a lively exchange. Some of the texts in this collection are well known and widely quoted, such as the invitation of Brahmā or the nun Vajirā’s simile of the person as a chariot. Most of the suttas here have parallels in the Chinese Saṁyuktāgama translations; the partial translations SA 2 and SA 3 include Sagāthāvagga material. In addition, many of the verses have parallels elsewhere throughout the Buddhist literature in all languages.
children: [{'uid': 'sn1', 'root_name': 'Devatāsaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With Deities ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses on Deities” contains 81 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a deity. Typically a deity approaches the Buddha in the monastery at Sāvatthī, illuminating the night with their glory. The deity addresses the Buddha with a question or verse, which may be a praise, a challenge, a riddle, or simply a reflection. The Buddha responds, usually elevating the discourse to a higher plane. As always in Buddhist texts, a deity is not worshiped, but is regarded as a temporary rebirth in a higher plane; the deities learn from the Buddha, not the other way around. In most cases, the narrative framework is slim, and after a while it is dropped entirely, retaining just the verses. There’s no particular theme to the discourses, which range from the simple to the profound.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 1', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 162}, {'uid': 'sn2', 'root_name': 'Devaputtasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses on Gods ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses on Gods” contains 30 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a god. Here the term devaputta is used, rather than devatā in the previous saṁyutta. The difference is purely nominal and there is no difference in the meaning. The style of discourses is similar to the “Linked Discourses on Deities”, although here there is a greater emphasis on the theme of renunciation. A number of these discourses are regularly recited in modern Theravāda; the Tāyana verses on diligent striving at SN 2.8 are often recited by monastics, while the discourses on the sun and the moon (SN 2.9 and SN 2.10) are popular protection chants, which are also found in Tibetan.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 2', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 31}, {'uid': 'sn3', 'root_name': 'Kosalasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With King Pasenadi of Kosala ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with the Kosalan” contains 25 discourses featuring King Pasenadi of Kosala. Pasenadi shines through in the early texts as a complex human figure, one with foibles and foolishness, but with a great devotion and capacity to grow. He appears frequently elsewhere in the suttas; MN 87 tells the story of how Queen Mallikā led him to the Dhamma. Here Mallikā appears again, and in SN 3.8 she shows how she is not afraid to challenge her king. The suttas in this collection typically set the verses in substantive prose narratives, illustrating the struggles and problems that beset a king intent on Dhamma who must nonetheless rule in a world with spies, sacrifices, punishments, wars, and the many temptations of royal life.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 3', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 25}, {'uid': 'sn4', 'root_name': 'Mārasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With Māra ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Māra” contains 25 discourses featuring Māra, the god of temptation, deceit, and death. In these discourses, Māra typically appears in some terrifying or beguiling form, hoping to disturb the Buddha, or else he challenges the Buddha with a critical verse. Like the previous section, the narrative prose here is substantive. The Buddha recognizes him at once and exposes his deceit in a verse. Māra also appears throughout the next collection, where the nuns take him on. ', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 4', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 50}, {'uid': 'sn5', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhunīsaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With Nuns ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Nuns” contains 10 discourses describing occasions when various nuns retreat to a forest for meditation, only to be challenged by Māra. The verses here partly overlap with the Therīgāthā, though there are some that are unique to this context, and we also have a prose narrative to flesh out the context. Māra’s challenges are various; sometimes he is sexist, alleging that women are weak in wisdom (SN 5.2). Several of these short texts are among the most frequently quoted of all the suttas.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 5', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 20}, {'uid': 'sn6', 'root_name': 'Brahmasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With Brahmā Gods ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Brahmās” contains 15 discourses featuring high brahmanical deities. Most commonly we meet the “Great Brahmā”, regarded as the creator God, but he is merely one of a class of deities, and here we meet several others. Brahmā is depicted here and elsewhere in early Buddhist texts in a respectful way, regarded as a glorious deity reborn in his realm due to powerful good kamma. As here, he frequently acts as a champion for the Buddhist cause. However, like all the gods, he is still under the influence of delusion and has nor escaped rebirth.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 6', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 15}, {'uid': 'sn7', 'root_name': 'Brāhmaṇasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses with Brahmins ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Brahmins” contains 22 discourses featuring the Buddha interacting with various members of the brahmanical caste. The brahmins were the custodians of the brahmanical scriptures and traditions, and saw themselves as the spiritual elite of society. A central platform of the Buddha’s ethical teaching was that one’s worth is determined by one’s deeds, not by caste. This was a direct challenge to brahmanical authority, and a number of discourses have an understandably combative air to them. But the brahmins were a diverse community, and it’s just as common to find them relating to the Buddha with respect and gratitude.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 7', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 22}, {'uid': 'sn8', 'root_name': 'Vaṅgīsasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses With Vaṅgīsa ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa” contains 12 discourses with verses spoken by Vaṅgīsa, the most renowned poet of early Buddhism. His verses have a sophistication and personal vulnerability that stamp them as perhaps the most distinctive literary voice of the early texts. Several of these discourses speak of his insecurities and struggles, and how he was helped to overcome them. Others speak from his joyous devotion to the Buddha and the Saṅgha, and of his final triumph.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 8', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 12}, {'uid': 'sn9', 'root_name': 'Vanasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses in the Woods ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses in the Woods” contains 14 discourses with verses telling the experiences of certain monks living the woods. Typically the monk is slack or negligent in some way, and a deity appears to call them out and encourage them to greater diligence.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 9', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 14}, {'uid': 'sn10', 'root_name': 'Yakkhasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses with Spirits ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': "The “Linked Discourses with Spirits” contains 12 discourses with verses telling the encounters between the Buddha—or in one case the monk Anuruddha—and various spirits (yakkha). The spirits were local deities worshiped in ancient India, of a lower order than the gods and Brahmās. While in later forms of Buddhism, such spirits were typically depicted as malevolent or dangerous, in the early texts they are more ambivalent, and many of them are friendly, merely asking Dhamma questions, or extolling Dhamma virtues like mindfulness. That’s not to say they couldn’t be scary, and several discourses reveal a more ferocious aspect. Particularly interesting is the emphasis on the love that the female spirits feel for their children.", 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 10', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 12}, {'uid': 'sn11', 'root_name': 'Sakkasaṁyutta', 'translated_name': 'Linked Discourses with Sakka ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The “Linked Discourses with Sakka” contains 25 discourses with verses telling stories involving Sakka, the Lord of the Thirty-Three gods. Many of these discourses are relatively lengthy, featuring substantive prose and extended dialogues in verse. Sakka is shown devoted to the Buddha, defending Buddhist virtues of kindness and forgiveness, even in the waging of war with the demons.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'SN 11', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 50}]

children: [{'uid': 'sn35.146', 'root_name': 'Kammanirodhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.146', 'blurb': 'The six interior sense fields are not yours, but are old kamma, generated by choices in past lives. This is explained in terms of the four noble truths.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.147', 'root_name': 'Aniccanibbānasappāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.147', 'blurb': 'The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.148', 'root_name': 'Dukkhanibbānasappāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.148', 'blurb': 'The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.149', 'root_name': 'Anattanibbānasappāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.149', 'blurb': 'The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn35.150', 'root_name': 'Nibbānasappāyapaṭipadāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.150', 'blurb': 'The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent, suffering, and not-self.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.151', 'root_name': 'Antevāsikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.151', 'blurb': 'One with no “student” and no “teacher” dwells in happiness. Here the Buddha plays with the Pali words such that “student” means “one who dwells within” and “teacher” means “one who assails”.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.152', 'root_name': 'Kimatthiyabrahmacariyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.152', 'blurb': 'If anyone asks why we live the holy life, it is for the ending of suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.153', 'root_name': 'Atthinukhopariyāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.153', 'blurb': 'How is it that a mendicant can declare their awakening? By understanding whether any desire arises from sense stimuli.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.154', 'root_name': 'Indriyasampannasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.154', 'blurb': 'One is accomplished in the sense faculties by being freed from attachment to them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.155', 'root_name': 'Dhammakathikapucchasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.155', 'blurb': 'A speaker on the Dhamma is someone who teaches for letting go of the senses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

[{'uid': 'ja51', 'root_name': 'Mahāsīlavajātaka', 'translated_name': 'King Great Morality ', 'acronym': 'Ja 51', 'blurb': '“Toil on, my brother.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who had given up all earnest effort. Being asked by the Master whether the report was true that he was a backslider, the Brother said it was true. “How can you, Brother,” said the Master, “grow cold in so saving a faith? Even when the wise and good of bygone days had lost their kingdom, yet so undaunted was their resolution that in the end they won back their sovereignty.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja52', 'root_name': 'Cūḷajanakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Tale of King Janaka ', 'acronym': 'Ja 52', 'blurb': '“Toil on, my brother.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another backsliding Brother. All the incidents that are to be related here, will be given in the Maha-janaka Jātaka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja53', 'root_name': 'Puṇṇapātijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Full Cup ', 'acronym': 'Ja 53', 'blurb': '“What? Leave untasted.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about some drugged liquor.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja54', 'root_name': 'Kiṁphalajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tree Named What-fruit ', 'acronym': 'Ja 54', 'blurb': '“When near a village.”—This was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay brother who was skilled in the knowledge of fruits. It appears that a certain squire of Savatthi had invited the Brotherhood with the Buddha at their head, and had seated them in his pleasaunce, where they were regaled with rice-gruel and cakes. Afterwards he bade his gardener go round with the Brethren and give mangoes and other kinds of fruits to their Reverences. In obedience to orders, the man walked about the grounds with the Brethren, and could tell by a single glance up at the tree what fruit was green, what nearly ripe, and what quite ripe, and so on. And what he said was always found true. So the Brethren came to the Buddha and mentioned how expert the gardener was, and how, whilst himself standing on the ground, he could accurately tell the condition of the hanging fruit. “Brethren,” said the Master, “this gardener is not the only one who has had knowledge of fruits. A like knowledge was shewn by the wise and good of former days also.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja55', 'root_name': 'Pañcāvudhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Five Weapons ', 'acronym': 'Ja 55', 'blurb': '“When no Attachment.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who had given up all earnest effort.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja56', 'root_name': 'Kañcanakkhandhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Mass of Gold ', 'acronym': 'Ja 56', 'blurb': '“When gladness.”—This story was told by the Master while at Savatthi, about a certain Brother. Tradition says that through hearing the Master preach a young gentleman of Savatthi gave his heart to the precious Faith and became a Brother. His teachers and masters proceeded to instruct him in the whole of the Ten Precepts of Morality, one after the other, expounded to him the Short, the Medium, and the Long Moralities, set forth the Morality which rests on self-restraint according to the Patimokkha, the Morality which rests on self-restraint as to the Senses, the Morality which rests on a blameless walk of life, the Morality which relates to the way a Brother may use the Requisites. Thought the young beginner, “There is a tremendous lot of this Morality; and I shall undoubtedly fail to fulfil all I have vowed. Yet what is the good of being a brother at all, if one cannot keep the rules of Morality? My best course is to go back to the world, take a wife and rear children, living a life of almsgiving and other good works.” So he told his superiors what he thought, saying that he proposed to return to the lower state of a layman, and wished to hand back his bowl and robes. “Well, if it be so with you,” said they, “at least take leave of the Buddha before you go;” and they brought the young man before the Master in the Hall of Truth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja57', 'root_name': 'Vānarindajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Monkey King ', 'acronym': 'Ja 57', 'blurb': '“Whoso, O monkey-king.”—This story was told by the Master, while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta’s going about to kill him. Being informed of Devadatta’s murderous intent, the Master said, “This is not the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta has gone about seeking to kill me; he did just the same in bygone days, but failed to work his wicked will.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja58', 'root_name': 'Tayodhammajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Three Qualities ', 'acronym': 'Ja 58', 'blurb': '“Whoso, like you.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove also upon the subject of going about to kill.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja59', 'root_name': 'Bherivādakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Drummer ', 'acronym': 'Ja 59', 'blurb': '“Go not too far.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain self-willed Brother. Asked by the Master whether the report was true that he was self-willed, the Brother said it was true. “This is net the first time, Brother,” said the Master, “that you have shewn yourself self-willed; you were just the same in bygone times as well.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja60', 'root_name': 'Saṅkhadhamajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Conch-blower ', 'acronym': 'Ja 60', 'blurb': '“Go not too far.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another self-willed person.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: Various dialogs with kings and princes, many of whom followed the Buddha.
children: [{'uid': 'mn81', 'root_name': 'Ghaṭikārasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 81', 'blurb': 'The Buddha relates an unusual account of a past life in the time of the previous Buddha, Kassapa. At that time he was not interested in Dhamma, and had to be forced to go see the Buddha. This discourse is important in understanding the development of the Bodhisattva doctrine.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'mn82', 'root_name': 'Raṭṭhapālasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 82', 'blurb': 'A wealthy young man, Raṭṭhapāla, has a strong aspiration to go forth, but has to prevail against the reluctance of his parents. Even after he became a monk, his parents tried to persuade him to disrobe. The discourse ends with a moving series of teachings on the fragility of the world.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn83', 'root_name': 'Maghadevasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 83', 'blurb': 'A rare extended mythic narrative, telling of an ancient kingly lineage and their eventual downfall.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'mn84', 'root_name': 'Madhurasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 84', 'blurb': 'In Madhurā, towards the north-eastern limit of the Buddha’s reach during his life, King Avantiputta asks Venerable Mahākaccāna regarding the brahmanical claim to be the highest caste.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn85', 'root_name': 'Bodhirājakumārasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 85', 'blurb': 'Admitting that he used to believe that pleasure was to be gained through pain, the Buddha explains how his practice showed him the fallacy of that idea.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn86', 'root_name': 'Aṅgulimālasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 86', 'blurb': 'Ignoring warnings, the Buddha ventures into the domain of the notorious killer Aṅgulimāla and succeeds in converting him to the path of non-violence. After becoming a monk Aṅgulimāla still suffered for his past deeds, but only to a small extent. He uses his new commitment to non-violence to help a woman in labor.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn87', 'root_name': 'Piyajātikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 87', 'blurb': 'A rare glimpse into the marital life of King Pasenadi, and how he is led to the Dhamma by his Queen, the incomparable Mallikā. She confirms the Buddha’s teaching that our loved ones bring us sorrow; but that’s not something a husband, father, and king wants to hear.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn88', 'root_name': 'Bāhitikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 88', 'blurb': 'King Pasenadi takes a chance to visit Venerable Ānanda, where he asks about skillful and unskillful behavior, and what is praised by the Buddha. He offers Ānanda a valuable cloth in gratitude.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn89', 'root_name': 'Dhammacetiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 89', 'blurb': 'King Pasenadi, near the end of his life, visits the Buddha, and shows moving devotion and love for his teacher.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn90', 'root_name': 'Kaṇṇakatthalasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 90', 'blurb': 'King Pasenadi questions the Buddha on miscellaneous matters: caste, omniscience, and the gods among them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}]

[{'uid': 'ja331', 'root_name': 'Kokilajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Cuckoo ', 'acronym': 'Ja 331', 'blurb': '“They that with speech inopportune”—This story was told by the Master at Jetavana about Kokalika. The introductory story is told in full in the Takkarika Birth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja332', 'root_name': 'Rathalaṭṭhijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Chariot-Whip ', 'acronym': 'Ja 332', 'blurb': '“Wounding another”—This story was told by the Master when he was at Jetavana, about the family priest of the king of Kosala, who, it is said, as he was driving in his chariot to a village on his estate came upon a caravan in a narrow road, and crying out once and again, “Out of the way with you,” was so enraged at a cart not clearing out of his way that he threw his goad-stick at the driver of the first cart.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja333', 'root_name': 'Pakkagodhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Cooked Lizard ', 'acronym': 'Ja 333', 'blurb': '“Then wert thou”—This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, of a certain landowner.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja334', 'root_name': 'Rājovādajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Kingly Advice ', 'acronym': 'Ja 334', 'blurb': '“The bull through floods”—This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana concerning the admonition of a king. The introductory story will be found in full in the Tesakuna Birth. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja335', 'root_name': 'Jambukajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 335', 'blurb': '“Jackal beware”—This story was told by the Master while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about the attempt of Devadatta to imitate the Buddha. The incident that gave rise to the story has been told in full before. Here is a short summary of it. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja336', 'root_name': 'Brahāchattajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Chatta the Tall ', 'acronym': 'Ja 336', 'blurb': '“Grass is still”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, of a certain rogue. The incident that suggested the story has been already related.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja337', 'root_name': 'Pīṭhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Seat ', 'acronym': 'Ja 337', 'blurb': '“Alas! we offered thee”—This story the Master told while living at Jetavana, about a certain Brother.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja338', 'root_name': 'Thusajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Grain by Grain ', 'acronym': 'Ja 338', 'blurb': '“With sense so nice”—This story was told by the Master while living in the Bamboo Grove, of prince Ajatasattu. At the time of his conception there arose in his mother, the daughter of the king of Kosala, a chronic longing to drink blood from the right knee of king Bimbisara (her husband).', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja339', 'root_name': 'Bāverujātaka', 'translated_name': 'Selling Crows to Babylon ', 'acronym': 'Ja 339', 'blurb': '“Before the crested peacock”—This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana, of certain heretics who lost their former gains and glory.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja340', 'root_name': 'Visayhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Merchant Visayha ', 'acronym': 'Ja 340', 'blurb': '“Of old, Visayha”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana of Anathapindika. The incident that gave rise to the story has been already told in full in the Khadirangara Birth. On this occasion the Master addressing Anathapindika said, “Wise men of old, my lay brother, gave alms, rejecting the counsel of Sakka, king of heaven, when he stood in mid-air and tried to prevent them, saying, “Give not alms.” And at his request the Master told a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'ja371', 'root_name': 'Dīghītikosalajātaka', 'translated_name': 'King Dīghīti of Kosala ', 'acronym': 'Ja 371', 'blurb': '“Thou art within my power”—This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning some quarrelsome folk from Kosambi.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja372', 'root_name': 'Migapotakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Fawn ', 'acronym': 'Ja 372', 'blurb': '“To sorrow for the dead”—This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told about a certain elder. It is said that he admitted a youth to orders, and that this novice, after ministering to him zealously, by and bye fell sick and died. The old man overcome with grief at the youth’s death went about loudly lamenting. The Brethren, failing to console him, raised a discussion in the Hall of Truth, saying, “A certain old man on the death of his novice goes about lamenting. By dwelling on the thought of death, he will surely become a castaway.” When the Master came, he inquired of the Brethren what was the subject they had met to discuss, and on hearing what it was he said, “Not now only, but formerly also, the old man went about lamenting, when this youth died.” And with this he related a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja373', 'root_name': 'Mūsikajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tale of Mūsikā ', 'acronym': 'Ja 373', 'blurb': '“People cry “Where is she gone”—This story the Master, whilst residing in the Bamboo Grove, told about Ajatasattu. The incident that led to the story has been already fully told in the Thusa Birth. Here too the Master observed the king at the same moment playing with his boy and also listening to the Law. And knowing as he did that danger to the king will arise through his son, he said, “Sire, kings of old suspected what was open to suspicion, and kept their heirs in confinement, saying, “Let them bear rule, after our bodies have been burned on the funeral pyre.” And with this he told a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja374', 'root_name': 'Cūḷadhanuggahajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Tale of Clever Little Archer ', 'acronym': 'Ja 374', 'blurb': '“Since thou hast gained”—This story was told by the Master whilst living at Jetavana, about the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. When the Brother confessed that it was owing to the wife that he had left, that he regretted having taken orders, the Master said, “Not now only, Brother, did this woman do you a mischief. Formerly too it was owing to her that your head was cut off.” And at the request of the Brethren he related a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja375', 'root_name': 'Kapotajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Pigeon ', 'acronym': 'Ja 375', 'blurb': '“I feel quite well”—This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a greedy Brother. This story of the greedy Brother has already been fully told in divers ways. In this case the Master asked him if he were greedy and on his confessing that it was so, said, “Not now only, but formerly also, Brother, you were greedy, and through greed came by your death.” And herewith he told a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Phoenixes” is the second of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “phoenixes” or supaṇṇas, otherwise known as garuḍa, powerful bird-spirits that are the natural antagonists to the dragons in Indian mythology.

blurb: This chapter, which has parallels in Chinese, and received an early commentary in the Niddesa, is often regarded as one of the earliest texts in the canon. Shorn of literary embellishments, it is direct and  powerful. A distinctive aspect is the critique of meaningless debates and attachments to views. The Attadaṇḍa Sutta gives an alternative account of the reasons for the Buddha’s going forth.

translated_name: The Iguana Who Befriended a Chameleon
children: [{'uid': 'ja141', 'root_name': 'Godhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Iguana Who Befriended a Chameleon ', 'acronym': 'Ja 141', 'blurb': '“Bad company.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about a traitorous Brother. The introductory incident is the same as that told in the Mahila-mukha jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja142', 'root_name': 'Siṅgālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 142', 'blurb': '“Thy tightening grip.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta’s going about to kill him. For, hearing the Brethren talking together as to this in the Hall of Truth, the Master said that, as Devadatta acted now, so he acted in times gone by, yet failed—to his own grievous hurt—of his wicked purpose. And so saying, he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja143', 'root_name': 'Virocanajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Shining ', 'acronym': 'Ja 143', 'blurb': '“Your mangled corpse.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta’s efforts to pose as a Buddha at Gayasisa.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja144', 'root_name': 'Naṅguṭṭhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tail ', 'acronym': 'Ja 144', 'blurb': '“Vile Jataveda.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, touching the false austerity of the Ajivikas, or naked ascetics.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja145', 'root_name': 'Rādhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tale of Rādha ', 'acronym': 'Ja 145', 'blurb': '“How many more?”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about hankering after the wife of one’s mundane life. The incidents of the introductory story will be told in the Indriya-jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja146', 'root_name': 'Samuddakākajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Crows Who Tried to Drink the Ocean ', 'acronym': 'Ja 146', 'blurb': '“Our throats are tired.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a number of aged Brethren. Whilst they were still of the world, they were rich and wealthy squires of Savatthi, all friends of one another; and tradition tells us that while they were engaged in good works they heard the Master preach. At once they cried, “We are old; what to us are house and home? Let us join the Brotherhood, and following the Buddha’s lovely doctrine make an end of sorrow.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja147', 'root_name': 'Puppharattajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Die of Flowers ', 'acronym': 'Ja 147', 'blurb': '“I count it not as pain.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who was passion-tost. Being questioned by the Master, he admitted his frailty, explaining that he longed for the wife of his mundane life, “For, oh sir!” said he, “she is so sweet a woman that I cannot live without her.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja148', 'root_name': 'Siṅgālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 148', 'blurb': '“Once bitten, twice shy.”—This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana, about subduing desires.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja149', 'root_name': 'Ekapaṇṇajātaka', 'translated_name': 'One Poison Leaf ', 'acronym': 'Ja 149', 'blurb': '“If poison lurk.”—This story was told about the Licchavi Prince Wicked of Vesali by the Master when he was living in the gabled house in the great forest near Vesali.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja150', 'root_name': 'Sañjīvajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Life-bringer the Student ', 'acronym': 'Ja 150', 'blurb': '“Befriend a villain.”—This story was told by the Master when at the Bamboo-grove, about King Ajatasattu’s adherence to false teachers. For he believed in that rancorous foe of the Buddhas, the base and wicked Devadatta, and in his infatuation, wishing to do honour to Devadatta, expended a vast sum in erecting a monastery at Gayasisa. And following Devadatta’s wicked counsels, he slew the good and virtuous old King his father, who had entered on the Paths, thereby destroying his own chance of winning like goodness and virtue, and bringing great woe upon himself.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: Asaṅga’s Yogacārabhūmiśastra, the “treatise on the stages of meditation practice” is one of the largest and most influential compendiums in northern Buddhism. While the overall structure is Mahayanist, several chapters focus on the early teachings and quote extensively from the Suttas. Not only is Asaṅga’s philosophical approach grounded in the teachnings of the Suttas, it is likely that this work, perhaps indirectly, inspired the creation of the Pali Visuddhimagga as a Theravadin equivalent.

blurb: The Buddha’s teachings on meditation, morality, the nature of the world, and the path to freedom. These scriptures are our primary sources for the historical Buddha’s life and practice. They depict the Buddha and his students in lively conversation with a diverse range of people.
