blurb: Discourses arranged as pairs of longer and shorter texts.
children: [{'uid': 'mn31', 'root_name': 'Cūḷagosiṅgasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga ', 'acronym': 'MN 31', 'blurb': 'The Buddha comes across three mendicants practicing diligently and harmoniously, and asks them how they do it. Reluctant to disclose their higher attainments, they explain how they deal with the practical affairs of living together. But when pressed by the Buddha, they reveal their meditation attainments.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn32', 'root_name': 'Mahāgosiṅgasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga ', 'acronym': 'MN 32', 'blurb': 'Several senior mendicants, reveling in the beauty of the night, discuss what kind of practitioner would adorn the park. They take their answers to the Buddha, who praises their answers, but gives his own twist.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn33', 'root_name': 'Mahāgopālakasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd ', 'acronym': 'MN 33', 'blurb': 'For eleven reasons a cowherd is not able to properly look after a herd. The Buddha compares this to the spiritual growth of a mendicant.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn34', 'root_name': 'Cūḷagopālakasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd ', 'acronym': 'MN 34', 'blurb': 'Drawing parallels with a cowherd guiding his herd across a dangerous river, the Buddha presents the various kinds of enlightened disciples who cross the stream of transmigration.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn35', 'root_name': 'Cūḷasaccakasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka ', 'acronym': 'MN 35', 'blurb': 'Saccaka was a debater, who challenged the Buddha to a contest. Despite his bragging, the Buddha is not at all perturbed at his attacks.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn36', 'root_name': 'Mahāsaccakasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse With Saccaka ', 'acronym': 'MN 36', 'blurb': 'In a less confrontational meeting, the Buddha and Saccaka discuss the difference between physical and mental development. The Buddha gives a long account of the various practices he did before awakening, detailing the astonishing lengths he took to mortify the body.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn37', 'root_name': 'Cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhayasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving ', 'acronym': 'MN 37', 'blurb': 'Moggallāna visits the heaven of Sakka, the lord of gods, to see whether he really understands what the Buddha is teaching.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn38', 'root_name': 'Mahātaṇhāsaṅkhayasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving ', 'acronym': 'MN 38', 'blurb': 'To counter the wrong view that a self-identical consciousness transmigrates from one life to the next, the Buddha teaches dependent origination, showing that consciousness invariably arises dependent on conditions.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn39', 'root_name': 'Mahāassapurasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Longer Discourse at Assapura ', 'acronym': 'MN 39', 'blurb': 'The Buddha encourages the mendicants to live up to their name, by actually practicing in a way that meets or exceeds the expectations people have for renunciants.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn40', 'root_name': 'Cūḷaassapurasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Discourse at Assapura ', 'acronym': 'MN 40', 'blurb': 'The labels of being a spiritual practitioner don’t just come from external trappings, but from sincere inner change.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Breakthrough” contains 11 discourses on the value of realizing the Dhamma. Each discourse features a memorable simile illustrating the truly momentous implications of seeing the four noble truths.

blurb: The Cūḷaniddesa or “Shorter Exposition” is really one half of a book together with the Mahāniddesa or “Great Exposition”. They offer commentaries on certain portions of the Sutta Nipāta, and lack counterparts in the northern canons. The Cūḷaniddesa comments on the “Way to the Beyond” and the “Rhinoceros Horn Sutta”.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Sāriputta” describes Sāriputta’s deep meditation practice, and his conversations with Ānanda, who noticed how radiant and glowing he was. An exception to this pattern is the final sutta, which depicts Sāriputta responding to the challenges of a female wanderer.

translated_name: The Chapter on Blind From Birth
blurb: Returning to stories about the Buddha’s life, this chapter skips ahead to near the end. Meanwhile, it reminds us of those who have lost their way.

The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has the four factors of stream-entry.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.23', 'root_name': 'Godhasakkasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.23', 'blurb': 'Mahānāma and Godhā the Sakyans discuss whether a stream-enterer has three or four factors. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.25', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasaraṇānisakkasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.25', 'blurb': 'When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.26', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamaanāthapiṇḍikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.26', 'blurb': 'When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Sāriputta reminds him of his considerable accomplishments in the Dhamma, analyzing stream-entry in ten factors, at which Anāthapiṇḍika recovers. Later he invited Sāriputta and Ānanda for a meal, and Sāriputta thanked him with verses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.27', 'root_name': 'Dutiyaanāthapiṇḍikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.27', 'blurb': 'When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Ānanda reminds him of the four factors of stream-entry, which Anāthapiṇḍika claims to possess.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.28', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamabhayaverūpasantasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.28', 'blurb': 'A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.29', 'root_name': 'Dutiyabhayaverūpasantasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.29', 'blurb': 'A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn55.30', 'root_name': 'Nandakalicchavisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 55.30', 'blurb': 'The Buddha teaches the four factors of stream-entry to Nandaka, the minister of the Licchavis. When his servant tells him it is time for his ritual bath, he says that the inner bathing of the Dhamma is enough.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Root of All Things
blurb: This chapter, though beginning with the abstruse Mūlapariyāya Sutta, mostly contains foundational teachings and can, as a whole, serve as an introduction to the discourses.
children: [{'uid': 'mn1', 'root_name': 'Mūlapariyāyasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Root of All Things ', 'acronym': 'MN 1', 'blurb': 'The Buddha examines how the notion of a permanent self emerges from the process of perception. A wide range of phenomena are considered, embracing both naturalistic and cosmological dimensions. An unawakened person interprets experience in terms of a self, while those more advanced have the same experiences without attachment.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn2', 'root_name': 'Sabbāsavasutta', 'translated_name': 'All the Defilements ', 'acronym': 'MN 2', 'blurb': 'The diverse problems of the spiritual journey demand a diverse range of responses. Rather than applying the same solution to every problem, the Buddha outlines seven methods of dealing with defilements, each of which works in certain cases.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn3', 'root_name': 'Dhammadāyādasutta', 'translated_name': 'Heirs in the Teaching ', 'acronym': 'MN 3', 'blurb': 'Some of the Buddha’s students inherit from him only material profits and fame. But his true inheritance is the spiritual path, the way of contentment. Venerable Sāriputta explains how by following the Buddha’s example we can experience the fruits of the path.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn4', 'root_name': 'Bhayabheravasutta', 'translated_name': 'Fear and Dread ', 'acronym': 'MN 4', 'blurb': 'The Buddha explains the difficulties of living in the wilderness, and how they are overcome by purity of conduct and meditation. He recounts some of the fears and obstacles he faced during his own practice.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn5', 'root_name': 'Anaṅgaṇasutta', 'translated_name': 'Unblemished ', 'acronym': 'MN 5', 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s chief disciples, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, use a simile of a tarnished bowl to illustrate the blemishes of the mind and conduct. They emphasize how the crucial thing is not so much whether there are blemishes, but whether we are aware of them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 4}, {'uid': 'mn6', 'root_name': 'Ākaṅkheyyasutta', 'translated_name': 'One Might Wish ', 'acronym': 'MN 6', 'blurb': 'According to the Buddha, careful observance of ethical precepts is the foundation of all higher achievements in the spiritual life.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn7', 'root_name': 'Vatthasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Simile of the Cloth ', 'acronym': 'MN 7', 'blurb': 'The many different kinds of impurities that defile the mind are compared to a dirty cloth. When the mind is clean we find joy, which leads to states of higher consciousness. Finally, the Buddha rejects the Brahmanical notion that purity comes from bathing in sacred rivers.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn8', 'root_name': 'Sallekhasutta', 'translated_name': 'Self-Effacement ', 'acronym': 'MN 8', 'blurb': 'The Buddha differentiates between peaceful meditation and spiritual practices that encompass the whole of life. He lists forty-four aspects, which he explains as “effacement”, the wearing away of conceit.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn9', 'root_name': 'Sammādiṭṭhisutta', 'translated_name': 'Right View ', 'acronym': 'MN 9', 'blurb': 'Venerable Sāriputta gives a detailed explanation of right view, the first factor of the noble eightfold path. At the prompting of the other mendicants, he approaches the topic from a wide range of perspectives.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}, {'uid': 'mn10', 'root_name': 'Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutta', 'translated_name': 'The Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation ', 'acronym': 'MN 10', 'blurb': 'Here the Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This collects many of the meditation teachings found throughout the canon, especially the foundational practices focusing on the body, and is regarded as one of the most important meditation discourses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 5}]

translated_name: The Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on the Sun
children: [{'uid': 'sn45.49', 'root_name': 'Kalyāṇamittasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.49', 'blurb': 'As the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the eightfold path.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn45.50-54', 'root_name': 'Sīlasampadādisuttapañcaka', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.50–54', 'blurb': 'As the dawn precedes the sun, ethics, enthusiasm, confidence, right view, and diligence precede the eightfold path.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn45.55', 'root_name': 'Yonisomanasikārasampadāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.55', 'blurb': 'As the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the eightfold path.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn45.56', 'root_name': 'Dutiyakalyāṇamittasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.56', 'blurb': None, 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn45.57-61', 'root_name': 'Dutiyasīlasampadādisuttapañcaka', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.57–61', 'blurb': None, 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn45.62', 'root_name': 'Dutiyayonisomanasikārasampadāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 45.62', 'blurb': None, 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

[{'uid': 'sn36.1', 'root_name': 'Samādhisutta', 'translated_name': 'Immersion ', 'acronym': 'SN 36.1', 'blurb': 'There are three feelings, and a meditator practicing immersion can understand them.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.2', 'root_name': 'Sukhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.2', 'blurb': 'There are three feelings, and all of them are suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.3', 'root_name': 'Pahānasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.3', 'blurb': 'One should give up desire for pleasant feeling, aversion for painful feeling, and ignorance regarding neutral feeling.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.4', 'root_name': 'Pātālasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.4', 'blurb': 'Ordinary people think the ocean is a bottomless abyss; but really, it is the three feelings.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.5', 'root_name': 'Daṭṭhabbasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.5', 'blurb': 'See pleasant feeling as painful, painful feeling as a dart, and neutral feeling as impermanent.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.6', 'root_name': 'Sallasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.6', 'blurb': 'Both ordinary and awakened people experience the three feelings. The difference is that when an ordinary person is stricken with feeling, they react, creating more suffering, whereas an awakened person responds with equanimity.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 3}, {'uid': 'sn36.7', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamagelaññasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.7', 'blurb': 'A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.8', 'root_name': 'Dutiyagelaññasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.8', 'blurb': 'A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.9', 'root_name': 'Aniccasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.9', 'blurb': 'The three feelings are impermanent.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn36.10', 'root_name': 'Phassamūlakasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 36.10', 'blurb': 'The three feelings are each produced by the appropriate contact.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter at the Cāpāla Shrine
children: [{'uid': 'sn51.1', 'root_name': 'Apārasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.1', 'blurb': 'The four bases of psychic power lead from the near to the far shore.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.2', 'root_name': 'Viraddhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.2', 'blurb': 'One who has neglected the four bases of psychic power has neglected the path to the end of suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.3', 'root_name': 'Ariyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.3', 'blurb': 'The four bases of psychic power are noble and emancipating.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.4', 'root_name': 'Nibbidāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.4', 'blurb': 'The four bases of psychic power lead to dispassion.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.5', 'root_name': 'Iddhipadesasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.5', 'blurb': 'Those who have developed psychic powers in part have developed the four bases of psychic power in part.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.6', 'root_name': 'Samattasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.6', 'blurb': 'Those who have developed psychic powers in full have developed the four bases of psychic power in full.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.7', 'root_name': 'Bhikkhusutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.7', 'blurb': 'Whatever mendicants realize perfection do so by developing the four bases of psychic power.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.8', 'root_name': 'Buddhasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.8', 'blurb': 'It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that the Realized One is called a Buddha.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.9', 'root_name': 'Ñāṇasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.9', 'blurb': 'On the night of his awakening, understanding and vision came to the Buddha regarding the four bases of psychic power.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn51.10', 'root_name': 'Cetiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 51.10', 'blurb': 'The Buddha says he could live to the end of the eon due to developing the four bases of psychic power. But Ānanda doesn’t get the hint.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Simile of the Vipers
children: [{'uid': 'sn35.238', 'root_name': 'Āsīvisopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.238', 'blurb': 'The Buddha strings a series of powerful similes—vipers, murderers, an empty village, and more—into an extended parable of the dangers of existence and the way of escape.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.239', 'root_name': 'Rathopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.239', 'blurb': 'When a mendicant has three qualities they live happily: sense restraint, moderation in eating, and wakefulness.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.240', 'root_name': 'Kummopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.240', 'blurb': 'A parable of a jackal who fails to eat a tortoise who stays still, with limbs retracted, like a mendicant guarding the senses.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn35.241', 'root_name': 'Paṭhamadārukkhandhopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.241', 'blurb': 'The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. A mendicant asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item. A cowherd named Nanda was listening, and determined to go forth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.242', 'root_name': 'Dutiyadārukkhandhopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.242', 'blurb': 'The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. Venerable Kimbila asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.243', 'root_name': 'Avassutapariyāyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.243', 'blurb': 'The Buddha is invited to teach in a new hall in Kapilavatthu. Late at night, after teaching the Sakyans, the Buddha invites Moggallāna to teach. He speaks on the mental corruption that flows from attachment to the senses. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.244', 'root_name': 'Dukkhadhammasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.244', 'blurb': 'The Buddha defines the things that entail suffering as the five aggregates, and urges mendicants to be free of desire for the six senses, giving a series of vivid similes. He then speaks of how even for a mendicant practicing restraint a lapse of mindfulness might occur from time to time.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.245', 'root_name': 'Kiṁsukopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.245', 'blurb': 'A mendicant goes to a series of teachers and asks how vision is purified. Dissatisfied with all their answers, he complains to the Buddha, who illustrates his quandary with the famous simile of the Kiṁsuka tree. Just as the same Kiṁsuka tree might be described differently by people focusing on the leaves, or the fruit, or the bark, etc., so too the various teachers each speak of the aspect of Dhamma most meaningful to them. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.246', 'root_name': 'Vīṇopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.246', 'blurb': 'One should restrain the senses like a farmer watching over a field. The Buddha gives the parable of a man bewitched when he first hears a lute. He takes apart the instrument in search of the sound, but is disillusioned when no sound is found.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.247', 'root_name': 'Chappāṇakopamasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.247', 'blurb': 'The senses are like a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, a jackal, and a monkey all tied up together, pulling this way and that. Mindfulness is like a post that keeps them grounded.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn35.248', 'root_name': 'Yavakalāpisutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 35.248', 'blurb': 'The six senses are like a sheaf of barley struck with six flails; and the desire for rebirth is a seventh flail. The Buddha goes on to speak of the cunning trap of the gods; but the trap of Māra, conceit, is even more subtle.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

[{'uid': 'ja151', 'root_name': 'Rājovādajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Kingly Advice ', 'acronym': 'Ja 151', 'blurb': '“Rough to the rough”—This story the Master told whilst he was living in Jetavana, to explain how a king was taught a lesson.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja152', 'root_name': 'Siṅgālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Jackal ', 'acronym': 'Ja 152', 'blurb': '“Who rashly undertakes”—This story the Master told while staying in his gabled chamber, about a barber who lived at Vesali.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja153', 'root_name': 'Sūkarajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Boar ', 'acronym': 'Ja 153', 'blurb': '“You are a fourfoot”—This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain Elder well stricken in years.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja154', 'root_name': 'Uragajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Snake ', 'acronym': 'Ja 154', 'blurb': '“Concealed within a stone”—This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a soldiers’ quarrel.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja155', 'root_name': 'Bhaggajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tale of Gagga ', 'acronym': 'Ja 155', 'blurb': '“Gagga, live an hundred years”—This story the Master told when he was staying in the monastery made by King Pasenadi in front of Jetavana; it was about a sneeze which he gave.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja156', 'root_name': 'Alīnacittajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Prince Braveheart ', 'acronym': 'Ja 156', 'blurb': '“Prince Winheart once upon a time”—This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a fainthearted Brother. The circumstances will be set forth in the Samvara Birth in the eleventh Book. When the Master asked this Brother if he really were fainthearted, as was said, he replied, “Yes, Blessed One.” To which the Master said, “What, Brother! in former days did you not gain supremacy over the kingdom of Benares, twelve leagues either way, and give it to a baby boy, like a lump of flesh and nothing more, and all this just by perseverance! And now that you have embraced this great salvation, are you to lose heart and faint?” And he told a story of olden days.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja157', 'root_name': 'Guṇajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Favors ', 'acronym': 'Ja 157', 'blurb': '“The strong will always have their way”—This was told by the Master whilst at Jetavana how Elder Amanda received a present of a thousand robes. The Elder had been preaching to the ladies of the king of Kosala’s palace as described above in the Mahasara Birth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja158', 'root_name': 'Suhanujātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Tale of Strongjaw ', 'acronym': 'Ja 158', 'blurb': '“Birds of a feather”—This story the Master told whilst at Jetavana, about two hot-tempered Brothers.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja159', 'root_name': 'Morajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Peacock ', 'acronym': 'Ja 159', 'blurb': '“There he rises, king all-seeing,” etc.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja160', 'root_name': 'Vinīlajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Goose Named Livid-blue ', 'acronym': 'Ja 160', 'blurb': '“As yonder king goes galloping”—This story the Master told during a sojourn in Veluvana, how Devadatta imitated the Buddha.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: Eighty short discourses in mixed prose and verse. These take the form of a simple prose narrative, which serves to frame an inspired saying, usually in verse. The udāna and dhammapada literature appear to overlap, and can be considered as one genre. The Dhammapada verses also have associated narratives, but these are found in the commentary. There are some indications that some of the narratives in the Udāna may be a little later than most of the material in the four main nikāyas.
children: [{'uid': 'ud-bodhivagga', 'root_name': 'Bodhivagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter on Awakening ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'This chapter begins with a series of discourses set immediately after the Buddha’s awakening, which are shared with the first chapter of the Khandhakas. It establishes the fundamental thesis of Buddhism: that awakening is possible through one’s own efforts. Each discourse deals with the idea of the true “brahmin”, defined not according to hereditary caste, but freedom from defilements.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'Ud 1', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 29}, {'uid': 'ud-mucalindavagga', 'root_name': 'Mucalindavagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter with Mucalinda ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The Buddha’s awakening has shown him a spiritual happiness that is better than any worldly happiness. This chapter focusses on the emotional dimension of enlightenment.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'Ud 2', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 24}, {'uid': 'ud-nandavagga', 'root_name': 'Nandavagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter with Nanda ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'The discourses in this chapter focus on equanimity in the face of pleasure and pain. There are several examples of monastic conduct of poise and balance.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'Ud 3', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 23}, {'uid': 'ud-meghiyavagga', 'root_name': 'Meghiyavagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter with Meghiya ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'If a practitioner fails to achieve such balance, their undisciplined mind leads to harming themselves and others.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'Ud 4', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 25}, {'uid': 'ud-sonavagga', 'root_name': 'Soṇavagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter with Soṇa ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'Broadening the focus from the individual practitioner, this chapter deals with the “all”, and shows how the Dhamma is inclusive of all beings, from kings to little fish.', 'node_type': 'branch', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': 'Ud 5', 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 23}, {'uid': 'ud-jaccandhavagga', 'root_name': 'Jaccandhavagga', 'translated_name': 'The Chapter on Blind From Birth ', 'acronym': None, 'blurb': 'Returning to stories about the Buddha’s life, this chapter skips ahead to near the end. [{'uid': 'sn47.11', 'root_name': 'Mahāpurisasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.11', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta asks the Buddha what is a great man, and the Buddha says it is someone whose mind has been freed by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.12', 'root_name': 'Nālandasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.12', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta boldly claims that no-one has ever, or will ever, be more enlightened than the Buddha. He admits that he cannot read the minds of all the Buddhas, but he understands a principle of the Dhamma: all those who become awakened do so by giving up the five hindrances, practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, and developing the seven awakening factors.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.13', 'root_name': 'Cundasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.13', 'blurb': 'Sāriputta dies of illness, and the novice Cunda together with Ānanda take his bowl and robes and report the sad news to the Buddha. The Buddha dispels Ānanda’s sadness by speaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.14', 'root_name': 'Ukkacelasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.14', 'blurb': 'After the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna (whose actual death is unrecorded in the canon), the Buddha says the Saṅgha looks empty; yet he is not sad.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.15', 'root_name': 'Bāhiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.15', 'blurb': 'When Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.16', 'root_name': 'Uttiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.16', 'blurb': 'When Venerable Uttiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.17', 'root_name': 'Ariyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.17', 'blurb': 'The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the end of suffering.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.18', 'root_name': 'Brahmasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.18', 'blurb': 'Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.19', 'root_name': 'Sedakasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.19', 'blurb': 'Two acrobats discuss whether one should support the other, or the other way around. The Buddha says they should support each other. In the same way we should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation both for one’s own benefit and to protect others.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'sn47.20', 'root_name': 'Janapadakalyāṇīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 47.20', 'blurb': 'A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That’s mindfulness! ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}]

[{'uid': 'ja521', 'root_name': 'Tesakuṇajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Three Birds ', 'acronym': 'Ja 521', 'blurb': '“’Tis this I ask”—This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told by way of admonition to the king of Kosala. Now this king came to hear the preaching of the law and the Master addressed him in the following terms: “A king, Sire, ought to rule his kingdom righteously, for whenever kings are unrighteous, then also are his officers unrighteous.” And admonishing him in the right way as related in the Catukkanipata (4th Book) he pointed out the suffering and the blessing involved in following or abstaining from evil courses, and expounded in detail the misery resulting from sensual pleasures, comparing them to dreams and the like, saying, “In the case of these men,', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja522', 'root_name': 'Sarabhaṅgajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Archer Sarabhaṅga ', 'acronym': 'Ja 522', 'blurb': '“Beringed and gallantly”—This was a story the Master, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, told concerning the death of the Elder, the Great Moggallana. The Elder Sariputta, after gaining the consent of the Tathagata when he was living at Jetavana, went and died in the village of Nala, in the very room where he was born.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja523', 'root_name': 'Alambusājātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Nymph Alambusā ', 'acronym': 'Ja 523', 'blurb': '“Then mighty Indra”—This story the Master, while residing at Jetavana, told about the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. The subject-matter of the tale is related in full in the Indriya Birth. Now the Master asked the Brother, “Is it true, Brother, that you were rendered discontented?” “It is true, Reverend Sir.” “By whom?” “By my wife of former days.” “Brother,” he said, “this woman wrought mischief for you: it was owing to her that you fell away from mystic meditation, and lay for three years in a lost and distracted condition, and on the recovery of your senses you uttered a great lamentation,” and so saying he told him a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja524', 'root_name': 'Saṅkhapālajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Dragon of Lake Saṅkhapāla ', 'acronym': 'Ja 524', 'blurb': '“Of comely presence”—This was a story told by the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, with regard to the duties of holy days. Now on this occasion the Master, expressing approval of certain lay folk who kept holy days, said: “Wise men of old, giving up the great glory of the Naga world, observed holy days,” and at their request he related a story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja525', 'root_name': 'Cūḷasutasomajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Shorter Tale of Prince Moonface the Scholar ', 'acronym': 'Ja 525', 'blurb': '“Good friends”—This story the Master while residing at Jetavana told concerning the perfect exercise of self-abnegation. The introductory story corresponds with that of the Mahanaradakassapa Birth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

blurb: 112 short discourses in mixed prose and verse, arranged in the Aṅguttara style of ascending numbered sets, from one to four. Alone among Buddhist texts, its survival is attributed not to the Saṅgha, but to a laywoman named Khujjuttarā. According to the Pali commentaries, she was a maid to the Queen of Kosambi, and memorized these teachings from the Buddha, earning her the title of the most learned of the laywomen disciples.

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields
blurb: The number of discourses in the “Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields” varies between editions, mainly due to the way repetitions are counted; SuttaCentral follows Bhikkhu Bodhi’s translation in counting 248 discourses. The six sense fields complement the five aggregates as the summary of the noble truth of suffering. Where the aggregates focus on the functional structure of experience as basis for views of self, the emphasis here is on how sense experience stimulates desire. Despite this difference in orientation, the two collections share much in common, and often the exact same template is applied in both cases. The six sense fields are the means through which the world is known, and so each of them has an “inner” and an “outer” aspect—the “eye” and “sights”, etc. Though common, it’s best to avoid thinking of the external sense field as the “object”, since in the suttas they are depicted in relation to the observing mind, and not as independently existing entities. This is straightforward until we come to the last sense, the “mind” and “thoughts” or “mental phenomena”. Just to clear up a possible confusion, this “sixth sense” is simply the mental faculty, and has nothing to do with psychic powers. The outer aspect is dhammā, a term so ambiguous its translation is always difficult. Here it refers to anything that may be known directly by the mind, distinct from the five senses. The most technically correct translation is probably “mental phenomena”, but “thought’ may be used as a more colloquial rendering, so long as it includes ideas, imagination, and so on, not just verbalized cognition.

blurb: Two fascicles compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救, T 210.4.559–574. It was brought by the Indian monk Vighna 維祇難 to Wuchang 武昌, China in 224 C.E., and translated by Zhu Jiangyan 竺將炎 and Zhi Qian 支謙. It is a collection of verses comprising the basic teachings of Buddhism which is similar to the Pali Dhammapada. The Chinese version contains 758 verses. There are four Chinese translations, dated CE 224, 290–306, 399, and 980–1001.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Breath Meditation” contains 20 discourses on breath meditation (ānāpānassati), the most revered form of meditation from early Buddhism until the present day. It was practiced by the Buddha himself. The meditation is taught in a detailed series of sixteen steps. These are partially sequential, but also overlap in some cases. The development of these fulfills all four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the seven factors of awakening. Thus this one form of meditation can lead to awakening; which is not, however, to say that it is invariably the best approach. The Buddha taught many different meditations for a reason; each has its own qualities and benefits. Breath meditation is seen as a peaceful and pleasant meditation which helps still distracting thoughts. It is a simple practice broadly suitable for most meditators, but leading to profound depths.

blurb: The Divyāvadāna or “Divine Tales” is a Sanskrit anthology of 38 tales, many originating in the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya. Typically the stories illustrate how the consequences of actions in past lives affect the present, with a special emphasis on the merit of making offerings to the Buddha and his disciples. It includes the famous Aśokāvadāna, one of the primary sources for the life of King Ashoka. The text probably dates from around the third century CE, but includes a few parallels to early texts. Modern editions are based on a number of Nepalese manuscripts, mostly quite modern. It was first edited and published in the west by Cowell and Neil in 1884. The digital text on SuttaCentral is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Vaidya (1959), with input by Kensuke Okamoto.

translated_name: The Spirit in the Clump of Grass
children: [{'uid': 'ja121', 'root_name': 'Kusanāḷijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Spirit in the Clump of Grass ', 'acronym': 'Ja 121', 'blurb': '“Let great and small.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about Anatha-pindika’s true friend. For his acquaintances and friends and relations came to him and tried hard to stop his intimacy with a certain man, saying that neither in birth nor wealth was he Anatha-pindika’s equal. But the great merchant replied that friendship should not depend on equality or inequality of externals. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja122', 'root_name': 'Dummedhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Lacking Intelligence ', 'acronym': 'Ja 122', 'blurb': '“Exalted station breeds a fool great woe.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta. For the Brethren had met together in the Hall of Truth, and were talking of how the sight of the Buddha’s perfections and all the distinctive signs of Buddhahood maddened Devadatta; and how in his jealousy he could not bear to hear the praises of the Buddha’s utter wisdom. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja123', 'root_name': 'Naṅgalīsajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Shaft of a Plough ', 'acronym': 'Ja 123', 'blurb': '“For universal application.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Laludayi who is said to have had a knack of always saying the wrong thing. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja124', 'root_name': 'Ambajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Mangoes ', 'acronym': 'Ja 124', 'blurb': '“Toil on, my brother.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a good brahmin belonging to a noble Savatthi family who gave his heart to the Truth, and, joining the Brotherhood, became constant in all duties. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja125', 'root_name': 'Kaṭāhakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Clever Young Man Kaṭāhaka ', 'acronym': 'Ja 125', 'blurb': '“If he ‘mid strangers.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a boastful Brother. The introductory story about him is like what has been already related.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja126', 'root_name': 'Asilakkhaṇajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Lucky Swords ', 'acronym': 'Ja 126', 'blurb': '“Our diverse fates.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a brahmin retained by the King of Kosala because of his power of telling whether swords were lucky or not. We are told that when the king’s smiths had forged a sword, this brahmin could by merely smelling it tell whether it was a lucky one or not. And he made it a rule only to commend the work of those smiths who gave him presents, while he rejected the work of those who did not bribe him.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja127', 'root_name': 'Kalaṇḍukajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Rascal Kalaṇḍuka ', 'acronym': 'Ja 127', 'blurb': '“You vaunt.”—This story was told by the Master once at Jetavana, about a boastful Brother. (The introductory story and the story of the past in this case are like those of Katahaka related above.)', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja128', 'root_name': 'Biḷāravatajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Hypocrite Like a Cat ', 'acronym': 'Ja 128', 'blurb': '“Where saintliness.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a hypocrite. When the Brother’s hypocrisy was reported to him, the Master said, “This is not the first time he has shewn himself a hypocrite; he was just the sane in times gone by.” So saying he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja129', 'root_name': 'Aggikabhāradvājajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Bhāradvāja, Servant of the Sacred Flame ', 'acronym': 'Ja 129', 'blurb': '“’Twas greed.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another hypocrite.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja130', 'root_name': 'Kosiyajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Woman Kosiya ', 'acronym': 'Ja 130', 'blurb': '“You may ail or eat.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a woman of Savatthi. She is said to have been the wicked wife of a good and virtuous brahmin, who was a lay-brother. Her nights she spent in gadding about; whilst by day she did not a stroke of work, but made out to be ill and lay abed groaning.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'sn46.153-164', 'root_name': 'Punabalakaraṇīyavagga', 'translated_name': 'Another Chapter on Hard Work ', 'acronym': 'SN 46.153–164', 'blurb': None, 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'ja81', 'root_name': 'Surāpānajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Drinking Liquor ', 'acronym': 'Ja 81', 'blurb': '“We drank.”—This story was cold by the Master about the Elder Sagata, while he was dwelling in the Ghosita-park near Kosambi.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja82', 'root_name': 'Mittavindakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'On Mittavindaka ', 'acronym': 'Ja 82', 'blurb': '“No more to dwell.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a self-willed Brother. The incidents of this Birth, which took place in the days of the Buddha Kassapa, will be related in the Tenth Book in the Maha-Mittavindaka Jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja83', 'root_name': 'Kāḷakaṇṇijātaka', 'translated_name': 'Unlucky ', 'acronym': 'Ja 83', 'blurb': '“A friend is he.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a friend of Anatha-pindika’s. Tradition says that the two had made mud-pies together, and had gone to the same school; but, as years went by, the friend, whose name was ‘Curse,’ sank into great distress and could not make a living anyhow. So he came to the rich man, who was kind to him, and paid him to look after all his property; and the poor friend was employed under Anatha-pindika and did all his business for him. After he had gone up to the rich man’s It was a common thing to hear in the house—“Stand up, Curse,” or “Sit down, Curse,” or “Have your dinner, Curse.” ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja84', 'root_name': 'Atthassadvārajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Gates of the Good ', 'acronym': 'Ja 84', 'blurb': '“Seek health.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a boy who was sage in matters relating to spiritual welfare. When he was only seven years old, the boy, who was the son of a very wealthy Treasurer, manifested great intelligence and anxiety for his spiritual welfare; and one day came to his father to ask what were the Paths leading to spiritual welfare. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja85', 'root_name': 'Kiṁpakkajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Unknown Fruit ', 'acronym': 'Ja 85', 'blurb': '“As they who ate.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a concupiscent Brother. Tradition says there was a scion of a good family who gave his heart to the Buddha’s doctrine and joined the Brotherhood. But one day as he was going his round for alms in Savatthi, he was there stirred to concupiscence by the sight of a beautifully dressed woman. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja86', 'root_name': 'Sīlavīmaṁsakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'A Test of Virtue ', 'acronym': 'Ja 86', 'blurb': '“Naught can compare.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a brahmin who put to the test his reputation for goodness. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja87', 'root_name': 'Maṅgalajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Omens ', 'acronym': 'Ja 87', 'blurb': '“Whoso renounces.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about a brahmin who was skilled in the prognostications which can be drawn from pieces of cloth. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja88', 'root_name': 'Sārambhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Ox Sārambha ', 'acronym': 'Ja 88', 'blurb': '“Speak kindly.”—This story was told by the Master while at Savatthi, about the precept touching abusive language. The introductory story and the story of the past are the same as in the Nandivisala-jataka above.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja89', 'root_name': 'Kuhakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Cheat ', 'acronym': 'Ja 89', 'blurb': '“How plausible.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a knave. [{'uid': 'ja11', 'root_name': 'Lakkhaṇamigajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Lucky Deer ', 'acronym': 'Ja 11', 'blurb': '“The upright man.”—This story was told by the Master in the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha about Devadatta. The story of Devadatta will be related, up to the date of the Abhimara-employment, in the Khandahala-jataka; up to the date of his dismissal from the office of Treasurer, in the Cullahamsa-jataka; and, up to the date of his being swallowed up by the earth, in the Sixteenth Book in the Samudda-vanija-jataka.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja12', 'root_name': 'Nigrodhamigajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Banyan Deer ', 'acronym': 'Ja 12', 'blurb': '“Keep only with the Banyan Deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the mother of the Elder named Prince Kassapa. The daughter, we learn, of a wealthy merchant of Rajagaha was deeply rooted in goodness and scorned all temporal things; she had reached her final existence, and within her breast, like a lamp in a pitcher, glowed her sure hope of winning Arahatship. As soon as she reached knowledge of herself, she took no joy in a worldly life but yearned to renounce the world. With this aim, she said to her mother and father, “My dear parents, my heart takes no joy in a worldly life; fain would I embrace the saving doctrine of the Buddha. Suffer me to take the vows.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja13', 'root_name': 'Kaṇḍijātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Dart ', 'acronym': 'Ja 13', 'blurb': '“Cursed be the dart of love.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the temptation caused to Brethren by the wives of their mundane life. This will be related in the Indriya-jataka in the Eighth Book. Said the Blessed One to the Brother, “Brother, it was because of this very woman that in bygone days you met your death and were roasted over glowing embers.” The Brethren asked the Blessed One to explain this. The Blessed One made clear what had been concealed from them by re-birth.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja14', 'root_name': 'Vātamigajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Wind-antelope ', 'acronym': 'Ja 14', 'blurb': '“There’s nothing worse.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Tissa, called Direct-alms the Less. Tradition says that, while the Master was dwelling at the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha, the scion of a wealthy house, Prince Tissa by name, coming one day to the Bamboo-grove and there hearing a discourse from the Master, wished to join the Brotherhood, but, being refused because his parents would not give their consent, obtained their consent by following Rattha-pala’s example and refusing food for seven days, and finally took the vows with the Master.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja15', 'root_name': 'Kharādiyajātaka', 'translated_name': 'With Kharādiya ', 'acronym': 'Ja 15', 'blurb': '“For when a deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about an unruly Brother. Tradition says that this Brother was unruly and would not heed admonition. Accordingly, the Master asked him, saying, “Is it true, as they say, that you are unruly and will not heed admonition?”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja16', 'root_name': 'Tipallatthamigajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Deer With Three Ruses ', 'acronym': 'Ja 16', 'blurb': '“In all three postures.”—This story was told by the Master while dwelling do the Badarika Monastery in Kosambi, about the Elder Rahula whose heart was set on observing the rules of the Brotherhood.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja17', 'root_name': 'Mālutajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Breeze ', 'acronym': 'Ja 17', 'blurb': '“In light or dark.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about two Brethren who had joined the Brotherhood in their old age. Tradition says that they were living in a forest-dwelling in the Kosala country, and that one was named the Elder Dark and the other the Elder Light. Now one day Light said to Dark, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the dark half of the month.” And one day Dark said to Light, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the light half of the month.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja18', 'root_name': 'Matakabhattajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Feasts for the Dead ', 'acronym': 'Ja 18', 'blurb': '“If folk but knew.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about Feasts for the Dead. For at this time the folk were putting to death goats, sheep, and other animals, and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead, for the sake of their departed kinsmen. Finding them thus engaged, the Brethren asked the Master, saying, “Just now, sir, the folk are taking the lives of many living creatures and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead. Can it be, sir, that there is any good in this?”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja19', 'root_name': 'Āyācitabhattajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Sacrifice to Fulfill a Wish ', 'acronym': 'Ja 19', 'blurb': '“Take thought of life hereafter.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the offering of a sacrifice under vow to gods. Tradition says that in those days folk when going a journey on business, used to slay living creatures and offer them as a sacrifice to gods, and set out on their way, after making this vow,—“If we come safely back with a profit, we will give you another sacrifice.” And when they did come safely back with a profit, the Idea that this was all due to gods made them slay a number of living creatures and offer them up as a sacrifice to obtain a release from their vow.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja20', 'root_name': 'Naḷapānajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Drinking With Straws ', 'acronym': 'Ja 20', 'blurb': '“I found the footprints.” This story was told by the Master whilst journeying on an alms-pilgrimage through Kosala, when he had come to the village of Nalaka-pana (Cane-drink) and was dwelling at Ketaka-vana near the Pool of Nalaka-pana, about cane-sticks. In those days the Brethren, after bathing in the Pool of Nalaka-pana, made the novices get them cane-sticks for needle-cases, but, finding them hollow throughout, went to the Master and said, “Sir, we had cane-sticks got in order to provide needle-cases; and from top to bottom they are quite hollow. Now how can that be?”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses on Arrival at the Truth
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Arrival” is the first of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items (shared also with SN 18 Rāhula) and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the distinction between those who accept the teachings by either faith or intellectual understanding, and those who have realized them for themselves.

children: [{'uid': 'sn7.1', 'root_name': 'Dhanañjānīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.1', 'blurb': 'When a brahmin lady expresses her confidence in the Triple Gem, her husband is annoyed. She encourages him to visit the Buddha, who soothes his anger.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.2', 'root_name': 'Akkosasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.2', 'blurb': 'A brahmin visits the Buddha and unleashes a tirade of abuse, but the Buddha refuses to accept it, showing that he remains free of anger.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.3', 'root_name': 'Asurindakasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.3', 'blurb': 'A brahmin visits the Buddha and abuses him, but the Buddha responds only with patience.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.4', 'root_name': 'Bilaṅgikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.4', 'blurb': 'Hearing that a brahmin had gone forth under the Buddha, another brahmin was upset. But once again the Buddha calms him down, pointing out that anger only harms oneself.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.5', 'root_name': 'Ahiṁsakasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.5', 'blurb': 'A brahmin called “Harmless” visits the Buddha, who teaches him the true meaning of harmlessness.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.6', 'root_name': 'Jaṭāsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.6', 'blurb': 'A brahmin with matted hair asks the Buddha how we can become disentangled. This short set of verses became one of the most important in all of Theravāda Buddhism when it was used as the cornerstone of the commentarial treatise Visuddhimagga (Path of Purification).', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.7', 'root_name': 'Suddhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.7', 'blurb': 'The brahmin Suddhika makes the strikingly Buddhist assertion that mere austerities don’t lead to purity; only knowledge and conduct do. ', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.8', 'root_name': 'Aggikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.8', 'blurb': 'A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice invites the Buddha to accept the blessed milk-rice, claiming that the Buddha is a true brahmin.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.9', 'root_name': 'Sundarikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.9', 'blurb': 'A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice wishes to offer the sacrificial cake. He sees the Buddha meditating and wants to give it to him, but hesitates when he realizes he is a shaven-headed ascetic. He asks the Buddha’s caste, but the Buddha argues that conduct is the important thing, not caste. The Buddha gives a metaphorical reinterpretation of the elements of brahmanical ritual.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'sn7.10', 'root_name': 'Bahudhītarasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'SN 7.10', 'blurb': 'A brahmin is searching for his lost oxen when he sees the Buddha meditating peacefully in the forest. He laments the many sorrows of his life, celebrating the Buddha’s happiness and freedom from such sorrows.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}]

[{'uid': 'ja101', 'root_name': 'Parosatajātaka', 'translated_name': 'Over a Hundred ', 'acronym': 'Ja 101', 'blurb': 'This story is in all respects analogous to the Parosahassa Jātaka (No. 99), with the sole difference that ‘think hard’ is read here.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja102', 'root_name': 'Paṇṇikajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Greengrocer ', 'acronym': 'Ja 102', 'blurb': '“He that should prove.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-brother who was a greengrocer in Savatthi and made a living by the sale of various roots and vegetables, and pumpkins and the like. Now he had a pretty daughter who was as good and virtuous as she was pretty, but was always laughing. And when she was asked in marriage by a family of his own station in life, he thought “She ought to be married, but she’s always laughing; and a bad girl married into a strange family is her parents’ shame. I must find out for certain whether she is a good girl or not.”', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja103', 'root_name': 'Verijātaka', 'translated_name': 'Enemies ', 'acronym': 'Ja 103', 'blurb': '“If wise, thou ‘lt loiter not.”—This story was told by the Master at Jetavana about Anatha-pindika. For we hear that Anatha-pindika was returning from the village of which he was headman, when he saw robbers on the road. “It won’t do to loiter by the way,” thought he; “I must hurry on to Savatthi.” So he urged his oxen to speed and got safely into Savatthi. Next day he went to the monastery and told the Master what had befallen him. “Sir,” said the Master, “in other times too the wise and good espied robbers on the road and hastened without delay to their homes.” Then at the merchant’s request he told this story of the past.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja104', 'root_name': 'Mittavindakajātaka', 'translated_name': 'On Mittavindaka ', 'acronym': 'Ja 104', 'blurb': '“From four to eight.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, concerning an unruly Brother. The incidents are the same as those in the previous story of Mittavindaka, but belong to the days of the Buddha Kassapa.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'ja105', 'root_name': 'Dubbalakaṭṭhajātaka', 'translated_name': 'The Weak Branch ', 'acronym': 'Ja 105', 'blurb': '“Fear’st thou the wind.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who lived in a perpetual state of nervous alarm. We learn that he came of a good family in Savatthi, and was led to give up the world by hearing the Truth preached, and that he was always in fear of his life both by night and by day. [{'uid': 'an10.91', 'root_name': 'Kāmabhogīsutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'AN 10.91', 'blurb': 'The Buddha teaches Anāthapiṇḍika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 1}, {'uid': 'an10.92', 'root_name': 'Bhayasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'AN 10.92', 'blurb': 'A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'an10.93', 'root_name': 'Kiṁdiṭṭhikasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'AN 10.93', 'blurb': 'Anāthapiṇḍika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha’s views. Anāthapiṇḍika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'an10.94', 'root_name': 'Vajjiyamāhitasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'AN 10.94', 'blurb': 'The householder Vajjiyamāhita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyamāhita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.', 'node_type': 'leaf', 'root_lang_iso': 'pli', 'root_lang_name': 'Pāli', 'child_range': None, 'yellow_brick_road': True, 'yellow_brick_road_count': 2}, {'uid': 'an10.95', 'root_name': 'Uttiyasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'AN 10.95', 'blurb': 'The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Faculties” contains 178 discourses on various sets of “faculties” (indriya). The “five faculties” of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom are the most natural fit in this context. However the chapter also finds room for discourses on a wider range of 22 faculties, including the six sense faculties, five affective faculties (kinds of feeling), three faculties relating the process of enlightenment, and three concerning biology and gender. This flexible category thus serves as a link between the teachings on wisdom and those on the path.

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Five Powers
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Five Powers” contains 108 discourses, which are, however, a mere instantiation of the standard repetition series as applied to the five powers. These powers are effectively identical with the five faculties, as stated at SN 48.43, being merely distinguished as a different teaching approach. There are several discourses on these qualities found mainly in the Aṅguttara Fives, but for some reason the redactors did not collect them here.

translated_name: The Chapter Beginning with One By One
blurb: Many of the discourses in this chapter delve into complex and analytical presentations of core teachings. It includes important discourses on meditation.
children: [{'uid': 'mn111', 'root_name': 'Anupadasutta', 'translated_name': None, 'acronym': 'MN 111', 'blurb': 'The Buddha describes in technical detail the process of insight of Venerable Sāriputta.
